                                "text": "The Islamic conquest of the Maghreb (North Africa) began in the mid-1st century AH / 7th century AD and lasted nearly seventy years . This expansion was not a random event but based on a well-structured military plan initiated by the Caliphs and governors . The conquest began with initial reconnaissance campaigns . Egypt served as a base to oversee the conquest of the Maghreb . In 22 AH/643 AD, Amr ibn al-Aas seized Cyrenaica with little resistance from the Luwata and Hawwara Berbers . He also captured Tripoli after a rapid siege . In 27 AH/647 AD, Abd Allah ibn Sa'd launched an attack against Byzacena and defeated the exarch Gregorius near Suffetula (Sbeitla) ."

Uqba ibn Nafi al-Fihri was appointed as governor of Africa by Caliph Muawiyah ibn Abi Sufyan around 50 AH/670 AD to continue the Islamic conquest . Uqba followed the coastal route and captured Jarmath . He also founded the city of Kairouan around 50 AH, which became a military center for Muslims . Uqba built a military camp near a high point called al-Qarn in the region of Qamunya, which later became the city of Kairouan ."

                                "text": "Idris I arrived in Volubilis (Walili) in 778-779 after allying with the Berber Awraba tribe . Rashid led Idris I to Volubilis from Mecca, passing through Egypt . The Jewish tribes took on a political role in the subjugation of Morocco to Idriss I . After conquering Tangier and Volubilis, Idriss I sought to persuade the Jewish tribes to join his army . Idriss I attacked and plundered some Jewish cities like Temesna, Chellah, and Magada, prompting Jews of Tadla, Fazaz, and Shawiya to join his army under \"general\" Benjamin-monta Joshaphat-monto Abiezer . After some successes, the Jewish contingent withdrew from Idriss I's army due to their aversion to bloodshed amongst their 'brothers' . Idriss I retaliated against the Jewish community after their withdrawal . The Jewish communities ultimately made peace with Idriss I, agreeing to pay a yearly capitation tax ."

                                "text": "While Idrīs I and Idrīs II are generally considered the founders of Muslim Morocco, Rāšid's role has been historically marginalized . Rāšid succeeded Idrīs I and ruled for approximately twelve years . Rāšid minted coins in his name in Volubilis and Tāhirt, the Rustamid capital . The oldest anonymous coins found in Fès were minted during Rāšid's reign, suggesting he may have founded the city . Some historians initially identified Rāšid b. Qādim as an Abbasid governor, but Moroccan archaeologists later suggested he was a local prince . It is now argued that Rāšid b. Qādim was the regent for Idrīs II during his minority . Fulūs of Rāšid b. Qādim found in Volubilis and Tahert are similar to those of Idrīs II (175/791-213/828) struck in Volubilis . The fulūs of Rāšid b. Qādim are also analogous to those of the Rustumid ʿAbd al-Wahhāb b. Rustum (r. 167/784-199/824) struck at Tahert and Tlemcen . The type of fulūs minted by the Idrisids and Rustumids is distinct from other coinage in the Maghreb at the time ."

                                "text": "Establishing a state requires a strong capital city as a base . Initially, the Idrisids resided in the city of Walili (Volubilis) . Idris ibn Abdallah founded Fes in the middle of the years 192 to 193 AH (Islamic calendar) . Idris II chose Fes as the capital, shifting it from Walili . The construction of Fez started on Thursday, Rabi’ al-Awwal 192 AH / 4 January 808 AD . Idris II founded Fez and made it the capital of the Idrisid state . Idris bin Abdullah built a city on the right bank of the Fez River in 172 AH / 789 AD . The historical city of Fez was considered the capital of the Idrisid state from the middle of the third century AH / ninth century AD . Favorable geographical and strategic factors allowed the Idrisid rulers to govern effectively from Fes . Fes became a hub for scholars, traders, and a successful industrial zone under Idrisid rule . The founding of the Medina of the Idrisids (VIII-IX centuries) led to the silting up of the travertine system ."

                                "text": "The Idrisid State flourished due to attention given to women and their views being incorporated into governance . Women in the Idrisid State played a vital role in intellectual life across culture, economy, scientific advancement, architectural art, and power structures . Kenza, wife of Idris I, was a key figure who provided advice to rulers and held a prominent position among the Berbers . Kenza was instrumental in maintaining the Zaydi ideology after the death of Idris I . Kenza influenced Idris I's decisions and played a role in dividing the Idrisid territories among his sons and grandsons . Fatima al-Fihri (Umm al-Banin) founded the al-Qarawiyyin mosque in Fez in 245 AH, which became a major center of learning . The construction of al-Qarawiyyin was financed by Fatima al-Fihri and involved using materials from the land she purchased, reflecting her religious commitment . Al-Qarawiyyin is considered the oldest university in the world still in operation . Maryam al-Fihri, Fatima's sister, founded the al-Andalusiyyin mosque in Fez . Atika bint Ali ibn Omar al-Idrisi played a key role in her father assuming power during a period of unrest ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Role of Women"
                    },

The Idrisids \"never established very firm or wide-ranging political or Shia religious authority, but it did bring Islam to the ‘Far West’ of the Muslim world\" .                                 "text": "The Fatimid Caliphate of Kairouan (297/909 to 567/1171) and the Umayyad Caliphate of Cordoba (138/756 to 422/1031) were two major powers vying for influence in the Maghreb . The Fatimids, a Shia Muslim dynasty, claimed descent from the Prophet Muhammad's daughter Fatima and sought to establish their rule in North Africa . They aimed to extend their control throughout the region and even into Egypt, challenging the Abbasid caliphate . The Umayyads, based in al-Andalus, also sought to exert their influence in North Africa . Previous analyses often prioritized the geopolitical rivalry between the Umayyads and Fatimids as the primary driver of conflict ."
                            }
                        ],

                                ],
                                "text": "The Fatimids utilized the Kutama Berber tribe to conquer the Aghlabids . A Fatimid missionary, Abu Abdallah, played a key role in this conquest . They extended their control throughout North Africa, controlling trade routes and commerce with sub-Saharan regions . However, the Fatimids faced resistance from the Kharijites and other groups .                                 ],
                                "text": "Al-Mu'izz, the last Fatimid ruler to spend significant time in Ifriqiya, transferred governance to the Zirid dynasty . The Zirids were a Berber dynasty who initially served as Fatimid vassals . However, the Zirids eventually broke away from Fatimid rule in 1048 . In response, the Fatimids sent the Banu Hilal and Banu Sulaym Arab tribes to Ifriqiya in 1051-1052 . These tribes, estimated at 50,000 warriors and 200,000 Bedouins, were given land grants (iqtâ') by the Fatimid caliph . The arrival of the Hilalian tribes is often characterized as an invasion, with devastating consequences for the region . Ibn Khaldun described the Hilal tribes as destructive nomads, contrasting their lifestyle with settled urban populations ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Zirids and the Hilalian Tribes"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://www.clio.fr/bibliotheque/pdf/pdf_les_invasions_hilaliennes_en_ifriqiya.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Hilalians' advance led to a devastating conflict with the Zirides, culminating in the fall of Kairouan after a five-year siege (1051-1056) . The Zirid dynasty fled to Mahdiya . The Hilalian tribes expanded throughout the eastern Maghreb, taking control of the plains and coastal areas, while the Berbers retreated to the mountainous regions . The fragmentation of Ifriqiya resulted in local authorities paying tribute to Hilalian chiefs . The Hilalians' impact on the region was seen as both negative (political fragmentation, economic disruption) and positive (cultural exchange, demographic shift) . Some historians argued that the Hilalian migrations were a consequence of the weakness of the urban centers in North Africa . The Hilalian tribes' arrival marked a turning point in the history of the Maghreb, introducing new dialects and impacting the cultural landscape of the region . The Hilalian tribes were eventually integrated into the Berber population, leading to a significant cultural and ethnic exchange . The arrival of the Hilalians marked a notable shift from classic Arabic to regional, vernacular dialects infused with Berber influences . Despite initial conflicts, some later Berbers and the Hilal tribes formed alliances and/or sought partnerships to maintain their respective power ."

                                "text": "The circulation of Sudanese gold in the 4th/10th century played a significant role in the political landscape of the Maghreb . The gold was extracted and refined in the Niger Bend, transported across the Sahara to the Maghreb, and then potentially to al-Andalus, the Latin West, or the Middle East . While the territorial disputes between the Umayyads and Fatimids are important, the gold trade from the Sudan to al-Andalus deserves more study . Examining the gold trade offers a new perspective on the 4th/10th century Maghreb before the rise of Berber dynasties . The author argues for a more comprehensive understanding that incorporates the gold trade's role ."

                "article_title": "Spain's Support for Morocco's Autonomy Plan for Western Sahara",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 1444,
                        "start": 1443

                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://www.mounier.es/attachments/article/111/cRamirez.pdf",
                                    "https://droit.cairn.info/revue-civitas-europa-2017-1-page-29?tab=texte-integral",

                                    "https://scielo.isciii.es/scielo.php?pid=S1132-12962016000200013&script=sci_arttext",
                                    "https://www.cairn.info/load_pdf.php?ID_ARTICLE=MACHR1_071_0028&download=1&from-feuilleteur=1"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Western Sahara conflict stems from the incomplete decolonization of the former Spanish colony . Spain colonized the territory in 1884, specifically the Rio de Oro peninsula . In 1961, Spain became the administrator under Chapter XI of the UN Charter, recognizing the right to self-determination of the inhabitants through a referendum . However, Morocco and Mauritania contested this position, claiming pre-existing legal links to the territories before Spanish colonization . The International Court of Justice (ICJ) considered the legal status of Western Sahara, specifically whether it was a *terra nullius* at the time of Spanish colonization . The ICJ found legal links of allegiance between the Sultan of Morocco and certain tribes in Western Sahara, but deemed these insufficient to establish territorial sovereignty ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://scielo.isciii.es/scielo.php?pid=S1132-12962016000200013&script=sci_arttext",
                                    "https://www.cairn.info/load_pdf.php?ID_ARTICLE=MACHR1_071_0028&download=1&from-feuilleteur=1",
                                    "https://www.cairn.info/load_pdf.php?ID_ARTICLE=MACHR1_083_0073&download=1&from-feuilleteur=1"
                                ],
                                "text": "In November 1975, the Madrid Accords were signed between Spain, Morocco, and Mauritania, leading to Spain's transfer of the Western Sahara territory to Morocco and Mauritania after a brief transition period . Spain transferred the administration, but not the sovereignty, of the Sahara to Morocco and Mauritania . The UN acknowledged the Madrid Accords (resolution 345 B of December 10, 1975) but also called for the Sahrawis' right to self-determination (resolution 345 A of the same date) . The Madrid Agreement proposed an exploitation scheme for the phosphate deposits with 65% participation by Morocco and 35% by Spain ."

Despite the absence of official diplomatic relations between 2000 and 2020, unofficial ties persisted, particularly in areas such as tourism and security . Approximately one million Moroccan Jews reside in Israel , and tens of thousands of Israelis visit Morocco annually . Secret relationships between Israel and Morocco existed from the 1950s to the 1970s, focusing on economic aid and Jewish emigration . King Hassan II engaged in discreet meetings with Israeli leaders, aiming to play a mediating role in Arab-Israeli relations . Liaison offices were exchanged in 1994 but closed in 2000 during the Second Intifada ."

                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://lup.lub.lu.se/student-papers/record/8514395/file/8514412.pdf",
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/SECUG_213_0103",
                                    "https://ujcontent.uj.ac.za/view/pdfCoverPage?instCode=27UOJ_INST&filePid=135966480007691&download=true",
                                    "https://www.xavier.edu/xjop/documents/vol3_2012/XJOP2012VolIIINo1Solomon.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Western Sahara is a disputed territory with a complex history. Colonized by Spain in the 19th century, both Morocco and Mauritania sought territorial gains in Western Sahara in 1971 . The indigenous Sahrawis, represented by the Polisario Front (PF), resisted these claims . The Polisario Front was formed in 1973 in Mauritania to fight for the independence of Western Sahara, initially against Spain and later against Morocco and Mauritania . In 1975, the UN International Court of Justice declared the Sahrawi people's right to self-determination over Western Sahara . In October 1975, the International Court of Justice ruled that self-determination was incompatible with Morocco's historical claims . In November 1975, King Hasan II ordered 300,000 Moroccans to march into Western Sahara in what became known as 'the Green March' . Spain withdrew from Western Sahara in 1976 without holding a referendum, deferring sovereignty to Morocco and Mauritania ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://lup.lub.lu.se/student-papers/record/8514395/file/8514412.pdf",
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/SECUG_213_0103",
                                    "https://ujcontent.uj.ac.za/view/pdfCoverPage?instCode=27UOJ_INST&filePid=135966480007691&download=true",
                                    "https://www.xavier.edu/xjop/documents/vol3_2012/XJOP2012VolIIINo1Solomon.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Polisario Front declared the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) in 1976 . Thousands of Sahrawi people fled to the Tindouf area of Algeria in 1976 and have resided in refugee camps there for nearly 40 years . Algeria has financially, militarily, and diplomatically supported the Polisario Front . Mauritania renounced its territorial claims in 1979, ceding territory to Morocco . Morocco built a 2700-kilometer Berm wall, manned by over 100,000 soldiers, on territory it controls . A settlement agreement was signed in 1991, envisaging a referendum on Sahrawi self-determination . The United Nations mission for the referendum on Western Sahara (MINURSO) was created . The referendum, originally envisaged for 1992, has not been instituted due to disagreements over voter eligibility . The UN views Western Sahara as a non-decolonized territory, not granting full sovereignty to Morocco but not explicitly legitimizing the SADR ."
                            }

                        "subtitle": "Historical Context of the Western Sahara Dispute"

                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journal-strategic.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/anglais4.pdf",
                                    "https://ujcontent.uj.ac.za/view/pdfCoverPage?instCode=27UOJ_INST&filePid=135966480007691&download=true",
                                    "https://www.xavier.edu/xjop/documents/vol3_2012/XJOP2012VolIIINo1Solomon.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Morocco identifies Western Sahara as part of a \"greater Morocco\" theory . Morocco left the OAU in 1984 following the admission of the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) . Morocco rejoined the African Union (AU) on January 30, 2017, after leaving in 1984 . Morocco's accession strategy involved numerous visits to francophone allies, economic agreements, and upgrading ties with Nigeria, South Africa, and Kenya . A key component of Morocco's strategy was to no longer make accession contingent on the de-recognition of the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) . Morocco believes the civil war in South Sudan has divided the independence drive among African states . Morocco believes counter-terrorism cooperation will ensure closer ties with the kingdom . Morocco believes low oil prices and leadership transition in Algeria will impair its support for the Polisario Front (PF) . Morocco believes its 2007 autonomy plan will soon be recognized as an optimal solution for the Western Sahara conflict . Morocco launched an autonomy initiative for Western Sahara in 2007 . The Moroccan initiative for Sahara autonomy was presented to the UN Secretary-General on April 11, 2007 . The Moroccan autonomy plan offers Sahrawi populations internal self-determination through free management of political, economic, social, and cultural affairs . The Moroccan plan excludes external self-determination to preserve Morocco's territorial integrity and national sovereignty . Rabat intends to retain exclusive powers in defense and external relations under the autonomy initiative . The autonomy statute is planned to be submitted to a referendum for the concerned populations ."

The Moroccan government has lobbied for the Security Council to keep the MINURSO mandate as it is . The US and France are mentioned as already being in favor of Morocco's 2007 autonomy plan . The US has historically been ambivalent towards the Maghreb, but post-9/11, Morocco's cooperation in the GWOT led to a Free Trade Agreement in 2004 . In April 2007, the US supported Morocco's proposal to give the Western Sahara \"meaningful autonomy\" under Moroccan sovereignty, despite it lacking a referendum, seemingly contradicting the US position on self-determination . The US has communicated to Morocco that the free trade agreement does not include the Western Sahara . In 2006, Gordon Gray, Under-Secretary for the Middle East and Maghreb Affairs, stated the US continues to seek a political solution acceptable to both Moroccans and Sahrawis within the UN framework and has no desire to impose a solution . Algeria, Morocco’s traditional rival, recognizes Sahrawi sovereignty . The Arab League identifies Western Sahara as exclusively Moroccan territory . The African Union views the SADR as a sovereign state . As of 2016, over thirty states that recognized Western Saharan independence have frozen or withdrawn SADR recognition . Twenty-eight states have formally advocated for the SADR's suspension from the AU . South Africa and Algeria continue to support the PF and SADR . Norway has adopted a strong stance against Morocco, advising its private actors not to get involved in Western Sahara, known as a policy of dissuasion . Only two other countries, the Netherlands and Denmark, in addition to Norway practice this policy of dissuasion . Sweden has taken a more ambiguous position, deciding in 2016 not to recognize the SADR ."

The US recognition was in exchange for Morocco re-establishing diplomatic ties with Israel . The United States played a role in facilitating the normalization of relations between Morocco and Israel . The United States recognized Moroccan sovereignty over the Western Sahara as part of the agreement leading to the establishment of official relations with Israel . Morocco and Israel have a long history of pragmatic geopolitical cooperation dating back to the mid-20th century . Israel's peripheral doctrine, conceptualized in 1957, influenced the relationship between Morocco and Israel . Morocco's King Hassan II maintained contacts with Israel despite pressures from other Arab states . Israel provided assistance to Morocco in its conflict in the Western Sahara ."
                            }

                        "subtitle": "Morocco-Israel Relations and the US Role"

Morocco subsequently annexed the region, a move contested by the Polisario Front, which, backed by Algeria, claims the territory and established the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) in 1976 . The Polisario Front seeks self-determination for the Sahrawi people . The conflict is a key aspect of the rivalry between Algeria and Morocco . Algeria supports the Polisario, hoping for a friendly state that provides an Atlantic outlet for exports . Morocco views Western Sahara as a natural and historical extension of its territory, seeking revenue from its phosphate and fish reserves ."

                                "text": "Despite the challenges, Baker's efforts culminated in the Madrid Peace Conference, which convened in October 1991 . Baker believed Syrian participation in the Madrid Conference after the 1991 Gulf War was crucial . Baker believed Assad's engagement in the Madrid Conference would legitimize the process and encourage other Arab partners . The conference brought together representatives from Israel, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, and the Palestinians . The US provided 'letters of assurance' to Israel, addressing concerns about the Palestinian issue, a new regional order, the Golan Heights, Lebanon, and the US alliance . The US 'letters of assurance' to the Palestinians mentioned the end of the Israeli occupation, legitimate political rights, the illegality of annexing East Jerusalem, opposition to settlement policies, and the possibility of a confederation . US 'letters of assurance' to Syria referred to the principle of restitution of the Golan and understanding of Arab grievances like the annexation of Jerusalem-East and settlements . US 'letters of assurance' to Lebanon addressed the implementation of Resolution 425 regarding Southern Lebanon ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The conflict in the Western Sahara stems from the region's colonial history and competing claims of sovereignty . From 1912 to 1956, Morocco was divided into French and Spanish protectorates, as well as the international zone of Tangiers . All protectorate arrangements were terminated in 1956 . In 1973, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro (Polisario Front) was formed, seeking independence for the Spanish Sahara . The development of a phosphate industry in the region laid the basis for a modern nationalist movement, with the Polisario Front pursuing an independent nation-state . The increased awareness among Saharawis about the prospect of an economically viable country due to phosphate resources contributed to mobilizing armed resistance against Moroccan control ."

                                ],
                                "text": "UN-monitored ceasefires are a crucial tool employed by the United Nations in its efforts to maintain international peace and security. These ceasefires, often implemented through peacekeeping operations, aim to halt hostilities, create space for diplomatic negotiations, and facilitate long-term conflict resolution . The success of these operations, however, depends on various factors, including the cooperation of the conflicting parties, the strength and clarity of the UN mandate, and the support of regional and international actors ."

These early missions, primarily involving unarmed observers, laid the foundation for future UN peacekeeping endeavors ."

                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s4_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://cyberleninka.ru/article/n/successes-and-failures-of-united-nations-peace-operations",
                                    "https://www.durham.ac.uk/media/durham-university/research-/research-centres/ibru-centre-for-borders-research/maps-and-databases/publications-database/boundary-amp-security-bulletins/bsb2-3_fetherston.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "* **UNTAG (Namibia):** This mission largely sustained the ceasefire between South African forces and SWAPO, overseeing the withdrawal of foreign troops and ensuring free and fair elections . However, a major offensive by SWAPO in April 1989 resulted in casualties on both sides . UNTAG also facilitated the return of refugees . Hage Geingob became the first leader of an independent Namibia in 1990 after the UNTAG mission .\n* **ONUMOZ (Mozambique):** This mission was mandated to monitor and support a ceasefire, demobilize forces, and oversee national elections . ONUMOZ partially implemented demobilization involving more than 76,000 soldiers and collected around 155,000 weapons . By December 1994, ONUMOZ facilitated the return of approximately 4.3 million people to their original homes .\n* **UNAMIR (Rwanda):** This mission lasted from October 1993 to March 1996 . The Rwandan genocide began on April 6, 1994, resulting in the murder of approximately 800,000 Rwandan Tutsis and Hutu moderates . The US initially refused to vote for expansion of UNAMIR .\n* **UNOSOM (Somalia):** UNOSOM II was deployed in March 1993 with a strength of 28,000 personnel . In March 1995, UNOSOM II completely withdrew from Somalia after suffering heavy casualties and failing to accomplish most of its mandate .\n* **MINURCA (Central African Republic):** This mission was authorized to improve the security situation in the Central African Republic, especially in the capital, and end the violence that had broken out in 1996-1997 .\n* **ONUB (Burundi):** The Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement was signed on 28 August 2000, formally ending a decade-long civil war in Burundi and leading to the formation and deployment of ONUB in 2004 . ONUB's mandate included overseeing the proper implementation of the Arusha Agreement, ceasefires, disarmament, and demobilization of militias ."

The UN Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO), established in May 1948, remains the UN's oldest ongoing peacekeeping operation . UNTSO was tasked with overseeing troop withdrawal and acting as a buffer between Israeli and Egyptian forces . The UN also brokered a cease-fire between Israeli and Palestinian forces in southern Lebanon in August 1979 . The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) was established in March 1978 to confirm the withdrawal of Israeli forces, restore international peace and security, and assist the Government of Lebanon in ensuring the return of its effective authority in the area ."

                                "text": "UN-monitored ceasefires are a vital component of the UN's broader efforts to maintain international peace and security . While these operations have faced numerous challenges and limitations, they have also played a crucial role in preventing conflicts, protecting civilians, and promoting long-term stability in various regions around the world . The success of UN-monitored ceasefires depends on a variety of factors, including the cooperation of the conflicting parties, the strength and clarity of the UN mandate, and the support of regional and international actors . As the nature of conflict continues to evolve, the UN must adapt its peacekeeping strategies and embrace new technologies to ensure the effectiveness of its efforts to maintain peace and security ."

The Saadian dynasty faced struggles against Spanish and Portuguese occupations in the north and the Ottomans in the east . The dynasty won the Battle of Oued Almakhazine (Battle of the Three Kings) . The Saadian empire reached its peak under al-Mançûr after 75 years of struggles and war . Ahmad al-Mansur reigned from 1578 to 1603 ."

                "article_title": "The Dila'ite Ascent and Fall: A History of the Zawiya of Dila'",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 1071,
                        "start": 1048
                    },
                    "milady": {
                        "end": 1660,
                        "start": 1638

                "event_name": "ثورة زاوية الدلاء",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/2260"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Zawiya of Dila' was founded around 1566 by ššix Abu Bakr ben Muḥammad El Mejjati Es-Ṣanḥaji (1536-1612) in central Morocco . Initially located near the qṣur of M‘ammar, approximately 10 kilometers southeast of Ayt Isḥaq, a more significant zawiya was later constructed in Ayt Ishaq itself . The Zawiya emerged as both a spiritual and temporal center of a Berber state, representing an attempt at Ṣenḥaja restoration . The Sa'adian rulers initially supported the Zawiya of Dila' . The marabouts of Dila' gained influence through their religious prestige, generosity, and their role in resolving disputes among transhumant Amazigh pastors in the Middle Atlas ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Foundation and Early Influence"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/2260"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Zawiya's sphere of influence encompassed the Ayt Idrassen confederation, which included tribes such as the Mejjat, Ayt Nḍir, Ayt Sadden, Ayt ‘Ayyaš, Ayt Yummur, Ayt Wallal, Ayt Wafella, and Imelwan . Initially, the Zawiya focused on Quranic teaching, conflict resolution, and providing hospitality . Its influence extended beyond the Middle Atlas, encompassing the entire Amazigh country, including the High Moulouya and the eastern High Atlas . The Zawiya established links with the qṣar of Tabu‘asamt in Tafilalt to facilitate trade between Saharan people and mountain dwellers . The zawiyas of Sidi Hamza and Sidi Bu Ya‘qub became relays of Dila'ite influence . Around 1630, the Ayt Yafelman alliance was created under Dila'ite influence to counter Semlalite expansionism . Zawit Aḥanṣal was associated with the Dila'ite movement in 1645/46 ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Expansion and Tribal Alliances"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/2260"
                                ],
                                "text": "Muḥammad ElḤajj aimed for temporal power, leading to the creation of a solid base and an army . A second zawiya was created on the site of Zawiya des Ayt Ishaq, along with a fortified city . In 1638, Muḥammad ElḤajj confronted and defeated the Sa'adian power near the Oued L‘abid . In 1641, Dila'ite troops occupied Salé, ousting El ‘Ayyaši, and controlled the lucrative commerce of the coastal city for nearly two decades . In 1646, Muḥammad ElḤajj won the battle of Lgara against the Alawites . Following the victory against the Alawites in 1646, the Dilaïtes entered Tafilalt . A pact designated the Jbel El ‘Ayyaši as the border between Dila'ite and Alawite influence zones, with Dila' gaining five strategic fortresses . By 1659, Muḥammad Elḥajj was named sultan in Fes ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Rise to Power and Conflict"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [

                                ],
                                "text": "The history of the Iberian Peninsula is marked by numerous sieges, dating back to ancient times. The sieges of Saguntum (218 BCE) and Numantia (134-133 BCE) stand as legendary national landmarks, representing heroic resistance against invaders . The siege of Saguntum by Hannibal in 219 BC, which escalated into the Second Punic War, and the siege of Numantia by the Roman Empire became symbols of perseverance and heroic defense . The Roman perspective on the siege of Saguntum was often exaggerated for ideological purposes . The Celtiberian settlement of Numantia, near modern Soria, chose suicide and destruction over surrender to Scipio Aemilianus in 133 BCE . This act of defiance has been reinterpreted throughout Spanish history to inspire resistance against foreign powers and promote national unity . Cervantes's play, *La destrucción de la Numancia*, reflects the public's fascination with sieges and stages elements of positional warfare as dramatic tropes ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Mawlay Ismail, who reigned from 1672 to 1727, played a crucial role in the definitive unification of Morocco . He consolidated his control over the country and marshaled its military capabilities to a remarkable degree . The Alaouite dynasty, to which Mawlay Ismail belonged, occupied Marrakech in 1659, effectively ending the existence of the two previous large kingdoms . Before this definitive unification, European texts referred to Morocco using the names of various territorial entities, primarily the kingdoms of Fez and Morocco . The definitive incorporation of these two kingdoms occurred during Mawlay Ismail's long reign . After his reign, the name \"Morocco\" came to represent the whole country in European languages and was used in diplomatic treaties signed by the Alawite dynasty ."
                            }

                                "text": "Mawlay Ismail's reign was marked by numerous military campaigns and a complex foreign policy, particularly concerning Algeria and the Ottoman Empire . Relations with Algeria were characterized by frequent clashes and short-lived truces . In 1679, a force led by Mawlay Ismail was defeated by the Algerians . In 1682, a Moroccan expedition pillaged the Banī ʿĀmir tribe in Algerian territory . In 1688, the Algerian \"Turks\" came to Mawlay Ismail to conclude peace . In 1692, another Moroccan force moved against Algeria but was checked, leading to a truce . In 1694, Moroccan forces raided Algerian territory while the dey of Algiers dealt with Tunis . In 1695-96, a Moroccan expedition commanded by Mawlay Ismail's son Aḥmad was defeated by the Algerians, prompting Mawlay Ismail to redeploy forces from the Ceuta siege . In 1696, Mawlay Ismail concluded another truce with the Algerians, aided by a letter from the Ottoman Sultan . In 1699-1700, Mawlay Ismail's son, Zaydān, led a foray into the Tlemcen area but concluded a truce, angering his father . In 1701, Mawlay Ismail undertook an expedition into Algeria but was defeated by the dey of Algiers . In 1707, Mawlay Ismail again entered Algeria, reportedly seeking to take Oran, but was defeated by Spanish forces ."

He also sought to confirm his equality with the Ottoman Sultan in terms of protocol, prestige, and in the important field of the jihad . Mawlay Ismail stressed shared interests and beliefs, praising the Ottomans’ commitment to confront the Christian powers and their support for Mecca and Medina . He sought to establish Morocco’s primacy in conducting the jihad in the Maghrib and presented Morocco’s own efforts on behalf of the jihad as an equivalent to those of the Ottoman Sultan ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Songhay Empire flourished in West Africa, expanding its territory and trade, developing a strong military and government, and supporting learning and scholarship . It arose from the remains of the Mali Empire under Sonni Ali around 1464 . Gao served as the capital of the Songhay Sultanate . Sonni Ali Ber (1464-1492) and Askia Muhammad (1492-1539) oversaw a period of rapid expansion . Askia Muhammad initiated a golden age of peace and stability . Gao, Timbuktu, and Djenné were important administrative, scholarly, and trade centers . Timbuktu became prominent in the Sudan and known in the Muslim world, producing scholars . The Songhay territory included the Niger bend from Kebbi to Djenné, extending to the Teghâza mines and controlling the gold trade to North Africa . Askia Muhammad I made a pilgrimage to Mecca in 1496-1497 and was declared Caliph of Sudan . He expanded the Songhay Empire to its greatest extent, from Dendi to Sibiridugu and from Teghazza to the border of Yatenga . Askia Dawud (1549-1583) oversaw a period of economic and intellectual flourishing ."

However, internal disarray among Askia Muhammad's descendants weakened the Songhay state in the late 16th century . Internal conflicts and rebellions further weakened the empire . Askia Muḥammad IV Bâno's accession in 1586 led to civil war . Al-Saddīḳ, the balama of Timbuktu, revolted against Askia Muḥammad IV in 1588 but was defeated by Isḥāḳ II . The decline of trans-Saharan trade due to the great discoveries and Ottoman expansion in North Africa negatively affected the Moroccan economy . Since the 16th century, the Sharifian dynasty in Morocco attempted to revive the trans-Saharan trade . Sultan Muhammad al-Shaykh al-Mahdî aimed to control the trans-Saharan trade politically and militarily . Control of the salt mines in Taghaza and the gold mines in Ghana was desired to monopolize the trade of salt, gold, and slaves . Seizing the Songhay Empire was considered necessary to dominate the trans-Saharan trade . The Moroccan sultan Mulay Ahmed al-Mansur claimed ownership of the Teghazza salt mines . The salt mines of Teghazza were a source of conflict between the Songhay Empire and the sultans of Morocco . The Moroccan invasion of 1591 led to Songhay's capitulation . The Moroccan invasion in 1591 ended the age of the great medieval West African states . The Songhay army in 1591 at the battle of Tondibi numbered approximately 30,000 infantry and 10,000 cavalry . The Moroccan army comprised renegades, Andalusian refugees, and Moroccan soldiers from Dra'a and Fez . The army that conquered the Songhay Sultanate and established a pashalik in Timbuktu in 1591 was largely composed of soldiers from Andalousia and renegades . Andalusian refugees, expelled from Spain between 1492 and 1609, influenced the military power of Morocco through their knowledge of firearms . The expedition of Pasha Djūdar hastened the ruin of trade by ending the largest and most powerful empire in West Sudan by the 16th century ."

                                "text": "The conquest of Timbuktu led to the establishment of a pashalik ruled by the descendants of the Moroccan army, known as the Arma, until the 19th century . The Arma established garrisons between Djenné and Gao and made Tombouctou their capital . The Arma integrated into Songhay society through marriage with the politico-religious elite . The Arma developed a unique political system based on unanimous election and possible revocation of the Pasha, with a rotation of the function between divisions of the army from Marrakech and Fès . In the 1710s, Arma factions introduced multi-story buildings in Timbuktu to better defend against gunfire . After the conquest in 1591, most of the Andalusians and renegades returned to Morocco . Between 1591 and 1618, reinforcements primarily came from Arab-Berber populations in southern Morocco . After 1591, the Songhay ruler and his loyalists fled into the Niger valley . Moroccan authorities tried to prevent refugees from the Songhay empire from receiving assistance . The fall of the Songhay Sultanate in 1591 led to waves of refugees fleeing the Moroccan conquest . The Songhay Empire collapsed due to its internal contradictions following civil war and external pressure from Morocco in 1591 ."

                                "text": "The Saadian dynasty, claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad, emerged in Morocco in the early 16th century . Unlike previous dynasties such as the Almoravids, Almohads, and Marinids, the Saadians did not rely on *'asabiyya* (esprit de corps) for their rise to power . The Almoravids depended on the Sanhâja confederation, the Almohads on the Masmûda, and the Marinids on the Zanâta confederation . The Saadians originated in the Dra valley, specifically the Zagora region, in the 12th or 13th century . The political and ideological situation in Morocco around 1510 favored their emergence . The Saadians were Arabs, and their rule initiated a political, economic, and intellectual renaissance ."

On February 28, 1591, a Moroccan army reached Niger after 135 days of travel from Marrakesh . The Moroccan army was sent by Ahmad al-Mansur to defeat Askiah Ishaq II, the king of Songhay . The battle between the Moroccan and Songhay armies took place on March 13, 1591 . The Moroccan army's superior weaponry and discipline led to the slaughter of the Songhay army . Following the defeat, 'Sudan' (the land of the Blacks) submitted to Morocco . Sudan sent a tribute of 100,000 pieces of gold and 1,000 slaves to Marrakesh . Sudan also promised an annual *khiraj*/tribute to Morocco . Ahmad al-Mansur was given the epithet *al-Dhahabi* (the golden) due to the large quantities of gold he received .                                 "text": "The conflict in Western Sahara, a territory on the northwest coast of Africa, has been a major unresolved colonial question . The roots of the conflict lie in the competing claims of Moroccan irredentism and Sahrawi nationalism, stemming from the arbitrary nature of colonial borders . The territory, once known as Spanish Sahara, was colonized by Spain beginning in 1884 . In 1963, the United Nations declared Western Sahara a non-self-governing territory to be decolonized . The Frente Polisario (Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el-Hamra and Rio de Oro) was formed on May 10, 1973, to fight for the region's independence, initially against Spanish colonialism ."

                "event_name": "المسيرة الخضراء إلى الصحراء الغربية",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://www.wsrw.org/files/dated/2013-12-05/western_sahara_fisheries_legal_analysis_2013.pdf",
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-83523-1_6",
                                    "https://www.scirp.org/journal/paperinformation?paperid=142204",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781003149552-22/people-barriers-movement-art-salvatore-garfi",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315869544-8/cultural-heritage-conflict-threatened-archaeology-western-sahara-nick-brooks",
                                    "https://zaguan.unizar.es/record/147357/files/TAZ-TFG-2024-1524.pdf?version=1"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Green March (المسيرة الخضراء إلى الصحراء الغربية) was a pivotal event in the ongoing dispute over Western Sahara, a territory on the Atlantic coast of North Africa bordering Morocco, Mauritania, and Algeria . The territory, formerly known as Spanish Sahara , had been a Spanish colony since 1884 . Spain's colonization began with an expedition led by Emilio Bonelli under the presidency of Antonio Cánovas del Castillo, and a Real Decree in December 1884 proclaimed the territory between Cabo Bojador and Cabo Blanco (Rio de Oro) as a Spanish protectorate . Villa Cisneros (now Dajla) was founded as the first Spanish settlement . In 1963, the United Nations listed Western Sahara as a non-self-governing territory . In 1966, the UN General Assembly urged Spain to organize a referendum on self-determination for Western Sahara ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://afsaap.org.au/assets/aggad.pdf",
                                    "https://muse.jhu.edu/pub/1/article/593068/summary",
                                    "https://press.armywarcollege.edu/monographs/526/",
                                    "https://www.africabib.org/rec.php?RID=213093995",
                                    "https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-journal-of-international-law/article/stealing-of-the-sahara/9D856214FBB2D8828ED7E61560E6E32E"
                                ],
                                "text": "As Spain prepared to withdraw from Western Sahara, Morocco asserted its claim to the territory . Morocco had long opposed the independence of Mauritania, accusing the French in 1960 of attempting to partition Morocco by creating an artificial state called Mauritania . King Hassan II sought to integrate Western Sahara into Morocco, a move that was seen by some as an expansionist policy . The discovery of a phosphate mine at Bu-Craa in 1964 further intensified geopolitical interest in the region, attracting countries like Morocco, Spain, France, and the United States, who competed for control of the world fertilizer market ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Historical Context"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://www.wsrw.org/files/dated/2013-12-05/western_sahara_fisheries_legal_analysis_2013.pdf",
                                    "https://www.biicl.org/files/5999_dawidowicz_30-04-12_biicl.pdf",
                                    "https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-journal-of-international-law/article/stealing-of-the-sahara/9D856214FBB2D8828ED7E61560E6E32E"
                                ],
                                "text": "In 1974, Spain committed to holding a referendum in the first half of 1975 . Morocco protested, claiming Western Sahara as an integral part of its territory . The General Assembly requested an advisory opinion from the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Morocco's historical claim to Western Sahara in 1974 . On October 16, 1975, the ICJ concluded that pre-colonial ties between Western Sahara and Morocco did not imply sovereignty . The ICJ reaffirmed the right of self-determination applied to all Non-Self-Governing Territories, including Western Sahara ."
                            },

                                "text": "The construction of defensive walls in Western Sahara, also known as the \"Sand Wall\" or \"Berm,\" is a significant event in the ongoing conflict between Morocco and the Polisario Front . The conflict stems from Spain's withdrawal from the territory in 1975 and the subsequent occupation by Morocco and Mauritania, leading to a struggle for self-determination by the Sahrawi people, represented by the Polisario Front . The Western Sahara was colonized by Spain in 1884 . In 1973, the Polisario Front was founded as one of several factions fighting for independence from Spain . In November 1975, the Moroccan government mobilized 350,000 Moroccans to march into the Spanish Sahara in an event known as the Green March . The Madrid Accords, signed in November 1975, transferred the administration of Western Sahara from Spain to Morocco and Mauritania . This transfer, however, excluded Algeria and the Polisario Front . The Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) was proclaimed by the Polisario Front after Spain's withdrawal in 1976 ."

                                    "https://www.militarystrategymagazine.com/article/fortified-strategic-complexes/"
                                ],
                                "text": "Faced with a costly guerrilla war against the Polisario Front, Morocco began constructing a series of defensive walls, or \"berms,\" in August 1980 . Construction was completed in 1987 . The walls were built in six stages . The purpose of these walls was to secure phosphate production, protect the \"useful triangle\" including Al-Ayoun, Smara, and Bou Craa, and seal off the territory from attacks by the Polisario Front . The construction and maintenance of the wall has occupied the bulk of national military effort for the last thirty years . The United States provided intelligence assistance for the building of the defensive wall in the desert . France, the United States, and Saudi Arabia supported the construction of the berm ."

                                    "https://www.scielo.org.mx/pdf/rz/v35n138/v35n138a14.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The defensive wall system is approximately 2,700 km long . It consists of sand and stone walls, barbed wire, minefields, and electronic equipment . The walls are three to four meters high . The gaps along the wall are covered by high fences, multiple layers of barbed wire, electronic surveillance devices, and approximately seven million land mines . Forts are located every three to five miles along the wall, manned by as many as 100,000 Moroccan soldiers . The walls were defended by approximately 160,000 Moroccan troops . The Moroccan army installed surveillance systems along the wall, including alarm systems and radars . The radar systems used include Rasura and AN/PPS-15, capable of detecting movements within a 60 km radius . The external main line of the walls follows the approximate line of the border with Algeria and Mauritania ."

                                "text": "The construction of the defensive walls had a significant impact on the conflict . The walls limited the effectiveness of Polisario raids and allowed the resumption of phosphate production . By building the walls, Morocco was able to consolidate its defenses and react more quickly to Polisario attacks . The walls cut the Western Sahara into two territories: the Moroccan-occupied zone and the POLISARIO-controlled zone . The berm bisects Western Sahara, dividing Sahrawis . The wall separates Saharawis in Moroccan-occupied territory from POLISARIO-liberated areas and refugee camps in Algeria . The construction of the wall led the Sahrawi army to transition from guerrilla warfare to a war of attrition . The wall negatively impacts the social, psychological, political, and economic aspects of Sahrawi life, including family separation, restricted movement, and hindering a referendum of self-determination . The Sahara Occidental has become the zone with the highest density of landmines due to the Moroccan wall's construction . More than 2,500 victims have been registered since 1975 due to the minefields around the Moroccan wall ."

In 1982 the United States and Morocco signed a joint military agreement, U.S. Green Berets were dispatched to the territory to help train and advise Moroccan forces, and the U.S. began providing intelligence assistance for the building of a defensive wall in the desert . U.S. support for Morocco, and the building of the berm in particular, was fundamental to its success in securing and maintaining control over most of the Western Sahara territory . France also supported Morocco, including its involvement in the Green March and the provision of military aid . The construction of the wall lasted for seven years with the aid of France and the United Kingdom . International bodies do not recognize Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara . The UN's MINURSO mission in Western Sahara is the oldest peacekeeping operation in Africa, established in 1991 . The MINURSO mandate has been prevented from expanding to include the monitoring of human rights due to opposition from Spain and France ."

                                "text": "The borders inherited from colonization are a primary source of disputes between Algeria and its neighbors . The newly independent nations of the Maghrib inherited political problems, particularly concerning frontiers, from their former imperial ruler, France . French colonial policies were largely responsible for the divisive border issue in North Africa, complicated by varying concepts of statehood and long-standing historical problems . When France conquered Algiers in 1830, they did not initially plan to take all of Algeria, and there was no clear concept of an Algerian state or consciousness . French expansion in North Africa brought the colonialists into direct conflict with Morocco, the Beylik of Tunis, and Algerian dissidents ."

Maghrebi governments are ambivalent about irregular migration, viewing it as a means for their populations to access better economic opportunities . Commodity smuggling, the irregular cross-border movement of goods such as petrol, is widespread across the region's borders and is a mainstay of borderland populations' livelihoods . Absent external pressure, Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia address irregular migration as akin to cross-border commodity smuggling and do not view enforcement as a high priority . Maghrebi states tolerate significant cross-border smuggling and irregular migration partly because of the need to ensure political stability in economically marginalized regions ."

            {
                "article_title": "The Ifni War: Spain's Last Colonial Conflict in North Africa",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 1377,
                        "start": 1376
                    },
                    "milady": {
                        "end": 1958,
                        "start": 1957
                    }
                },
                "event_name": "حرب إفني ضد إسبانيا",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/7716991.pdf",
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-17230-5_3",
                                    "https://revistas.grancanaria.com/index.php/aea/article/view/9301",
                                    "https://revistas.uned.es/index.php/ETFV/article/download/41670/31409",
                                    "https://scielo.isciii.es/scielo.php?pid=S1887-85712024000400005&script=sci_arttext&tlng=en",
                                    "https://vbn.aau.dk/files/763146352/Bresc_Ignacio_Between_the_Unbearable_Weight_and_Lightness_of_the_past_accepted_manuscript.pdf",
                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1973_num_15_1_1227"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Ifni War, also known as the Forgotten War, took place between 1957 and 1958 in the Spanish territories of Ifni and Sahara in Northwest Africa . Spain's interest in the area dates back to the 15th and 16th centuries with the establishment of Santa Cruz de Mar Pequeña, a Spanish enclave on the African Atlantic coast near the Canary Islands . This enclave was maintained for about 50 years . The reconquest of this territory became an objective for Spanish governments, especially during the second half of the 19th century . Spain's victory in the War of Africa (1859-1860) against Morocco positioned Santa Cruz de Mar Pequeña as a potential war prize . Negotiations between Spanish monarchs and Moroccan sultans eventually led to Spain's establishment in Sidi Ifni in 1934 . A Spanish column occupied the Ait Ba 'Amran territory at Sidi Ifni in April 1934 without resistance . Ifni became a military garrison and administrative headquarters of Spanish West Africa . The effective occupation of Ifni happened in 1934, during the Second Spanish Republic, led by Colonel Osvaldo Capaz ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Historical Context: Spanish Presence in Ifni"
                    },

                        "paragraphs": [

                                ],
                                "text": "The Ifni War occurred during the Francoist dictatorship and the decolonization and expansion of Morocco in the mid-20th century . Morocco gained independence in 1956 . The war was Spain's last colonial war in North Africa . The conflict was framed by the Franco regime as an invasion by guerrillas of the 'Army of Liberation' rather than an open war between Morocco and Spain . The Sultan of Morocco, Mohamed V, avoided openly declaring against Spanish interests, placing responsibility on the Armed Bands of Liberation (BAL) . The Armed Bands of Liberation (BAL) were a group that acted as the armed wing of the Istiqlal party . The BAL consisted of individuals who had participated in the independence of Morocco but hadn't integrated into the Royal Armed Forces . The initial BAL mobilization involved attacking the airfield and armory in Sidi Ifni, and other Spanish positions . The attack on Sidi Ifni, the capital of the province, occurred on November 23, 1957 ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Outbreak of War and Francoist Spain"

                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://scielo.isciii.es/pdf/sm/v80n1/1887-8571-sm-80-01-18.pdf",

                                    "https://scielo.isciii.es/scielo.php?pid=S1887-85712024000400005&script=sci_arttext&tlng=en"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Spanish military aviation carried out reconnaissance, combat, transport, rescue, and salvage missions using aircraft like HA 112, Texan T-6, HA211, Junker Ju-52, Douglas C-47, Dornier Do27, E-9, Grumman HU-16, and S55 . The Spanish Air Force executed 2179 sorties, 328 recognitions, 33 aerial supplies, 34 paratrooper launches, 1234 transport services, 40 casualty evacuations, 71 liaisons, and 33 escort and salvage missions . The Air Force transported 6263 men, 976,379 kg of supplies, launched 420 paratroopers, dropped 13,200 kg of material over besieged positions, and evacuated 243 casualties . The Spanish Navy played an important logistical role, including transporting troops and supplies . Naval units were organized into two groups, each consisting of two cruisers and three or four destroyers, supported by a frigate, corvettes, minelayers, and tugboats . Twelve civilian ships were used to transport troops and supplies from the Iberian Peninsula and Canary Islands . The Spanish Navy deployed a Marine Corps contingent to establish a beachhead at El Aaiún . Naval vessels provided artillery support during joint operations with the Spanish Army and Air Force . The first expeditionary company of the Marine Infantry was formed on January 16, 1958, with 222 men, including a medical lieutenant and health personnel, and deployed to El Aaiún . El Aaiún beach was a key point during the campaign and was attacked by insurgent bands on November 25, 1957 ."
                            }

Total casualties in the Ifni War are estimated at around 800, including deaths, injuries, and disappearances . Medical officers of the Armada provided health support on ships and at the Marine Corps detachment on El Aaiún beach . Naval hospitals like San Carlos (Cádiz) and the antituberculosis sanatorium in Madrid treated casualties from the conflict . The medical support system consisted of a stepped approach, starting at the front line, continuing at civilian hospitals in Spanish West Africa, evacuating severe cases to the Military Hospital of Las Palmas, and ultimately to mainland Spain if needed . The Sikorsky S-55 H-19 helicopter was used for the first time in combat for medical evacuations during this conflict ."

                                "text": "The Franco regime censored the Ifni War, leading to it being largely forgotten in Spain . The Spanish press manipulated information through concealment, propaganda, language manipulation, blaming communism, and historical manipulation . The press did not refer to the conflict as a 'war,' but rather used euphemisms like 'incidents,' 'operations of cleaning,' or 'disturbances' . The Ministry of Information and Tourism enforced censorship based on the 'Serrano Súñer Law' of 1938, dictating press serves the state . The Spanish media emphasized the heroism of Spanish troops and the gradual return to normalcy . Following the Ifni War, there was a tacit agreement among media outlets to bury the dead and their memory . The Spanish authorities tried to blame the Soviet Union and international communism for inciting the incidents during the Ifni War ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Sand War (حرب الرمال), a conflict between Algeria and Morocco, took place in September-October 1963 . The war stemmed from a territorial dispute, specifically in the Béchar and Tindouf border regions . Morocco attempted to reclaim the Tindouf and Béchar areas, claiming they were annexed to French Algeria by France decades earlier . The conflict was influenced by ill-defined borders inherited from the colonial period . Regional problems in North Africa originate from boundary formation during the colonial period . The absence of a precise border, the discovery of mineral resources, and Moroccan irredentism fueled by the Greater Morocco ideology contributed to the conflict ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://dspace.zcu.cz/bitstreams/f80b4b15-c541-4be8-b7af-9a49586e8f42/download",

                                    "https://fi.wikiital.com/wiki/Guerra_delle_sabbie"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Treaty of Lalla Maghnia (March 18, 1845) defined only 165 km of the border between French Algeria and Morocco . Article 4 of the treaty stated that there was no territorial limit to establish in the Sahara, and both sovereigns would exercise their rights over their respective subjects . In the 1890s, France annexed the Touat, Gourara, and Tidikelt, which had been part of the Moroccan Empire for centuries . France integrated Tindouf and Colomb-Bechar into the French departments of Algeria in 1952 . Morocco sought the return of disputed territories after gaining independence in 1956 ."

In September 1957, serious incidents occurred between the Moroccan Liberation Army (ALM) and the Algerian Liberation Army (ALN), with over 90 Algerian fighters disarmed . In the week of Algeria's potential civil war in late July 1962, Moroccan forces raised the Sharifian flag on Zegdou and Saf Saf posts in southwestern Algeria ."

On October 29, the Moroccan and Algerian leaders prepared to go to Bamako to negotiate and end their dispute . On October 30, 1963, Ben Bella and Hassan II arrived in Bamako, joined by the Prime Minister of Mali and the ruler of Ethiopia . A ceasefire agreement was reached in Bamako, set to begin on November 2 at 0h00 . The Charte d'Addis Abeba was created, including the decisions from the Bamako conference, setting up a cease-fire, troop withdrawal, demilitarized border zone, and the creation of the Organisation of African Unity (OUA) . The OUA members accepted the inviolability of borders designated during colonialism by European colonizers . An OAU agreement on February 20, 1964, led to the status quo ante bellum, with the borders favoring Algeria . A demilitarized zone was established and monitored by multinational peacekeepers under the OAU . A formal armistice was signed on February 20, 1964 ."

Ben Barka condemned the Moroccan border claims as a betrayal of the global liberation movement . During the Sand War, Algeria was supported by the majority of Third World countries, Egypt, Cuba, and the Eastern Bloc, while Morocco was supported by the Western world . The Sand War can be considered an episode of the Cold War ."

Algeria, under President Boumédiène, supported the Polisario Front . One reason for Algeria's support of Polisario was the humiliation of Algeria by Morocco in the \"War of the Sands\" in 1963 ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Western Sahara War, also known as the Western Sahara conflict, is a protracted struggle for control of the Western Sahara, a territory in Northwest Africa bordering Morocco, Algeria, Mauritania, and the Atlantic Ocean . The conflict's roots lie in the decolonization era, specifically the withdrawal of Spain from the territory in 1975 . Spain began colonizing the Western Sahara in 1884, a process that wasn't fully completed until 1936, after which the territory became known as Spanish Sahara . In 1975, as Spanish colonial authorities were preparing a referendum on independence, Morocco invaded the territory . Spain transferred its colonial authority to Morocco and Mauritania in 1975, a move the UN largely deemed illegitimate ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "The primary parties involved in the conflict are the Kingdom of Morocco and the Polisario Front (Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia el Hamra and Rio de Oro) . Morocco claims sovereignty over Western Sahara, viewing the territory as an integral part of the Kingdom . The Polisario Front, formed in 1973, seeks full independence for Western Sahara and represents the aspirations of the Sahrawi people for a national state . Algeria has been a key supporter of the Polisario Front, providing rear bases, arms, training, and diplomatic support . Mauritania was initially involved, occupying part of Western Sahara following the Madrid Accords of November 14, 1975, but withdrew in 1979 ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "Following Spain's withdrawal, Morocco and Mauritania militarily invaded Western Sahara before it was formally decolonized . The invasion was opposed by the Sahrawi population organized around the Polisario Front . The Polisario Front, formed in 1973, waged a fifteen-year guerrilla struggle against Mauritania and Morocco . By 1979, the Polisario rebels eliminated Mauritanian forces, leading Morocco to seize control of Western Sahara’s southern region . From 1980 to 1987, Morocco built a system of earthen berms, supplemented with landmines, extending 1,690 miles (2,700 kilometers) from southwest to northeast of Western Sahara, as a military strategy . The 'Berm' is manned by 150,000 soldiers and controls 85% of the territory, while the Polisario controls the remaining 15% . The conflict caused the displacement of 100,000 to 150,000 people and resulted in the death of thousands of fighters ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The War (1975-1991)"

                        "paragraphs": [

                                ],
                                "text": "A UN-sponsored cease-fire in 1991 resulted in Morocco controlling most of Western Sahara . The UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO) attempted to implement a plan for a plebiscite in the 1990s, but disagreements arose regarding voter eligibility . The UN mission arrived in Western Sahara with the intention of solving the conflict within 12 months, but remains there . The UN Security Council issued a resolution calling for negotiations between the parties without preconditions, aiming for a just, lasting, and mutually acceptable political solution that provides for self-determination for the people of Western Sahara . The UN has regarded the Western Sahara issue as a matter of decolonization and has defined its resolution in terms of self-determination since 1991, following the UN-brokered ceasefire and the deployment of MINURSO ."
                            }

                        "subtitle": "The Ceasefire and the Stalled Referendum"

                                "text": "King Hassan II of Morocco died in mid-1999, and his son, Mohammed VI, subsequently rejected independence for Western Sahara . Morocco offered autonomy to Western Sahara but refuses to allow an independence option . In 2007, Morocco presented a formal autonomy proposal, which Polisario rejected without an independence vote option . Peter van Walsum, the departing UN envoy, stated that Morocco decided in April 2004 not to accept any referendum with independence as an option . James Baker, former US Secretary of State, proposed a period of autonomy followed by a vote, which Polisario accepted but Morocco vetoed . Christopher Ross has been the U.N. envoy to Western Sahara since 2008 . Morocco has essentially stopped negotiating and attempted to have Christopher Ross dismissed in 2013 ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The conflict has been influenced by various international actors and their shifting alliances . During the Cold War, Morocco portrayed the conflict as a proxy war between East and West, seeking U.S. support against Polisario . The Reagan administration provided Morocco with arms in the 1980s, helping it regain territory lost in the early years of the war . After 9/11, Morocco attempted to portray Polisario as susceptible to 'Jihadism' to maintain U.S. support . The United States has consistently supported Morocco in the conflict . France is accused of blocking progress by protecting Morocco in the Security Council . Spain and France are involved due to their historical colonial roles . The EU is implicated through a fisheries agreement with Morocco in Saharan waters . In June 2004, the U.S. awarded Morocco a free trade agreement and major non-NATO ally status . Spain has abandoned its long-standing position of neutrality on Western Saharan independence from Morocco . In March 2022, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez sent a letter to the King of Morocco expressing support for the Moroccan autonomy proposal of 2007 as a resolution to the Western Sahara conflict . In December 2020, then-US President Donald Trump recognized Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara, conditional on the normalization of relations between Morocco and Israel . France, the United States, Israel, and Spain are backing Rabat (Morocco) in the Western Sahara dispute . This backing is to the detriment of Algeria, which supports statehood for the Sahrawi people ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "The conflict has resulted in significant human rights abuses and humanitarian concerns . Refugee camps housing Sahrawis were established in Tindouf, Algeria, in 1976 . Tens of thousands of Saharawis live in these camps . The Moroccan occupation threatens the Sahrawi nation and potentially leads to a more radical fight from Polisario . MINURSO's mandate is limited to ceasefire monitoring and it does not monitor human rights . Sahrawi human rights activists face harsh sentences and degrading conditions in Moroccan prisons ."

Morocco has exploited Western Saharan phosphates since its forces moved into the territory . The EU's relationship with Western Sahara, including economic engagement, is ad hoc and influenced by geopolitical and legal factors . The European Commission conducted public consultations in Western Sahara to examine the economic and human rights impacts of proposals ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The conflict in Western Sahara stems from the withdrawal of Spain in 1976 and the subsequent struggle for control of the territory . Spain's abandonment led to a division of the territory between Morocco and Mauritania . This division was opposed by the Polisario Front (Frente Popular de Liberación de Saguía el Hamra y Río de Oro), a Sahrawi liberation movement seeking independence for the region . The Polisario Front, representing the indigenous Sahrawi population, declared the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) in 1976 and initiated a guerilla war against the occupying forces of Morocco and Mauritania . The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled on October 16, 1975, that the Sahrawi tribes had the right to self-determination, rejecting Moroccan claims ."

Initially, Morocco focused on defense, controlling key cities and phosphate mines, while the Polisario launched attacks on supply lines . Mauritania, facing internal economic and ethnic tensions, was a weaker target and the focus of initial Polisario attacks, targeting economic targets like iron ore mines to turn the civilian population against the government ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Morocco's military strategy evolved over time. General Amed Dlimi reorganized the Moroccan military strategy in 1979, focusing on mobile units and relocating the civilian population . Beginning in 1981, Morocco constructed a defensive wall (Berm) system to isolate the Polisario and secure key areas . This wall system included barbed wire, trenches, fortifications, and extensive minefields . The wall aimed to protect approximately 80% of Western Sahara and included over 300 fortified positions . The construction of the wall significantly hampered Polisario's operations, limiting their ability to establish bases and launch attacks . Despite the wall, Polisario launched attacks against Moroccan forces throughout the 1980s ."

                                    "https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.7560/328439-009/html"
                                ],
                                "text": "The issue of border demarcation has been a recurring source of tension and conflict for Algeria, stemming largely from the artificial borders drawn during the colonial era . The Berlin Conference of 1884-1885 saw European powers carve up Africa, creating territories that reflected European compromises rather than African interests, leading to artificial borders that have caused suffering and conflicts in post-colonial Africa . The French colonial administration, which controlled Algeria for 132 years until its independence in 1962, gradually expanded its influence into areas claimed by neighboring Morocco, leading to future disputes . France's actions included the occupation of areas like Gurara, Tuat, and Tidikelt in 1900 and 1901, and the establishment of a \"line of operation\" in 1960 following the Draa River ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/4277948.pdf",

                                    "https://www.africabib.org/rec.php?RID=186152507"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Treaty of Lalla Marnia in 1845, intended to define the border between Morocco and Algeria, only delimited a section from Saidia to Teniet Sassi, leaving the southern territories undefined and setting the stage for future disagreements . The French exploited this ambiguity to expand into the Sahara, a move protested by Morocco . This expansion was further complicated by the discovery of mineral resources in the disputed territories, contributing to Algeria's stance on maintaining the inherited colonial borders ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Following Morocco's independence in 1956, the issue of defining borders was raised, with King Mohammed V claiming parts of southern Algeria as Moroccan territory . In 1958, Morocco withdrew from a joint Franco-Moroccan commission working to define borders . In July 1961, Morocco and the Provisional Government of Algeria (GPRA), led by Ferhat Abbas, signed an agreement concerning the border issue, recognizing that it would be resolved through negotiation between the two governments . However, after Algeria's independence in 1962, tensions arose, with military incidents around Tindouf . The Algerian constitution of 1963 affirmed the country's indivisibility, complicating Moroccan territorial claims ."
