The OAU's Council of Ministers established an Ad-Hoc Commission to mediate the Algerian-Moroccan dispute, but it was unsuccessful . The OAU's charter aimed to promote unity, solidarity, cooperation, sovereignty, territorial integrity, independence, and the eradication of colonialism in Africa . The OAU charter included a provision (Article 19) for the peaceful settlement of disputes among member states through a commission of mediation, conciliation, and arbitration . The AU's Constitutive Act of 2002 allows for interference in member states' internal affairs in cases of unconstitutional changes of government, human rights abuses, and conflicts threatening regional stability ."

                                    "https://theses.hal.science/tel-00648984v1/file/th2010PEST0023.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Al-Andalus, the area of the Iberian Peninsula under Muslim rule from 711 to 1492, experienced significant political and social changes in the centuries leading up to the Almoravid intervention . The initial Muslim conquest in 711 led to the establishment of Al-Andalus . The Umayyad dynasty ruled Al-Andalus from 756 CE . Cordoba flourished as a cultural center, excelling in science, philosophy, medicine, astronomy, poetry, and history . However, the Caliphate of Cordoba disintegrated after the death of Al-Mansur's son, Abd al-Malik, in 1008, giving rise to the Taifa states by 1031 . These Taifa rulers lacked the unity to effectively resist the Christian kingdoms in the north . Until the early eleventh century, Christian kingdoms in Spain suffered military defeats from Al-Andalus rulers . Al-Mansur (978-1002) led approximately fifty campaigns against the Christian north, sacking Barcelona in 985 and Santiago de Compostela in 997 . The Taifa period saw the end of a unified judicial policy in Al-Andalus . The political fragmentation and weakness in Al-Andalus created the conditions for the later Almoravid intervention ."
                            }

Almoravid epigraphy saw the use of marble and a more uniform, evolved cúfico script .                             {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://bokundoli.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/T3-6.pdf",

                                ],
                                "text": "The Almoravids (al-Murabitun), meaning \"monk warriors,\" emerged as a rigorous religious movement among the Sanhaja Berbers in the Sahara . Their origins can be traced to the 11th century, with a focus on legalistic piety and \"holy war\" against perceived moral laxity among Muslims . The Berber groups, Lamtuna, Massufa and Djuddala, converted to Islam superficially and later formed the core of the Almoravid movement . The movement was initiated by Yahyà Ibn Ibrahim in the Sahara desert . Abu Bakr and Yusuf Ibn Tashufin led the Almoravids in military expansion across North Africa . Yusuf Ibn Tasufin organized the Almoravids politically, conquering North Africa from 1055 ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Origins and Early Development"

                                "text": "The Almoravids violently attacked Awdāghust, citing the need to restore justice and abolish abusive taxes . By the end of the 11th century, the Almoravids eliminated the remnants of Kharijism, Shiism, and Barghawata heresy in the western Maghreb, establishing the dominance of the Maliki school of Sunni Islam . The Almoravid dynasty ruled Morocco from 1055 to 1130 and is credited with the foundation of Marrakech . Marrakech was founded by Yusuf Ibn Tashufin in 1070, drawing inspiration from Sijilmasa . The Almoravid emir Yusuf ibn Tashfin constructed the Qasr al-Hajar in 1070, establishing military architectural norms ."

The Almoravids overthrew Al-Muctamid after he defended Seville in 1091 . The Almoravids gained recognition as the supreme authority in Al-Andalus, establishing an empire from the Ebro River to the southern Sahara . The Almoravid rule was characterized by intolerance towards both lax Muslims and non-Muslims . The Almoravids entered the Iberian Peninsula in 1090 . The Almoravid empire spanned from the Ebro River to the Sahara ."

Almoravid walls in Marrakech and Al-Andalus used a stone base and tapial reinforced with lime . Almoravid walls often featured square towers at regular intervals . Almoravid walls also featured recessed entrances for improved defense ."

                                "text": "The Empire of Ghana, also known as Wagadu, was one of the earliest known political formations in West Africa . Arabic sources began mentioning 'Ghāna,' a ruler and city, in the 9th century due to trans-Saharan trade . The empire was known for its riches in gold and held a preeminent role in the western Sahel . The first mention of the empire of Ghana is found in the works of the astronomer El Fazzari just before 800 A.D. . Arabic writings mention that the Empire of Ghana had existed since the second century A.D. . The empire has been equated with the Soninké people’s legend of Wagadu . David Conrad argues that the Soninké knew the ancient kingdom as Wagadu . The word ‘Ghana’ means ‘king’; the inhabitants of the country were the Sarakole . El Bakri suggests 'Ghana' is a title meaning 'Chief of War' . Some believe the name 'Ghana' is derived from the Arabic adjective 'ghanna', meaning beautiful ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Archaeological investigations in southern Mauretania have revealed stone masonry villages occupied by prehistoric cultivators as early as 1000 B.C. . The inhabitants of these villages were likely Negro and very probably Soninke, with a culture developed largely without external influences . Around 600 B.C., Libyco-Berbers from North Africa arrived in the area . The initial effect of Libyco-Berber contact was the collapse of the existing sociopolitical organization . Subsequent adjustment, along with trans-Saharan trade carried out by North Africans, led to the re-emergence of the pre-existing pattern, resulting in the Ghana Empire . The prehistoric complex suggests a powerful chiefdom with characteristics of subsequent West African states ."

The primary causes of the fall of the Ghana Empire were internal conflicts and deteriorating climatic conditions, not the Almoravids . The theory that the Almoravids Islamized the Wagadu-Ghana has been refuted by historians from the historical school of Dakar, based on the analysis of written and oral sources .             {
                "article_title": "The Battle of Zallaqa: A Clash Between Castile and the Almoravids",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 478,
                        "start": 478
                    },
                    "milady": {
                        "end": 1086,
                        "start": 1086
                    }
                },
                "event_name": "معركة الزلاقة ضد قشتالة",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://freidok.uni-freiburg.de/files/229322/Clnqkajvvp4f5Ca0/9783956503085-115.pdf",
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-96481-2_9",
                                    "https://scholar.archive.org/work/xrdmjj5ltvewfcjhvmhs66ja74/access/wayback/https://collections.lib.utah.edu/dl_files/98/72/98723191318b34224000de8c5fffdca851e2bd56.pdf",
                                    "https://scholarworks.calstate.edu/downloads/qf85ng13c",
                                    "https://www.nomos-elibrary.de/de/10.5771/9783956503085-115.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Zallaqa, also known as the Battle of Sagrajas, took place in 1086 in the southwest region of al-Andalus, near the Portuguese border . This battle occurred during a period of significant political upheaval in the Iberian Peninsula, marked by the disintegration of the Umayyad Caliphate into various Taifa kingdoms . The Taifa period, lasting from 1013 to 1069, was characterized by competitive politics among these smaller kingdoms . This fragmentation created a power vacuum that was exploited by the expanding Christian kingdoms to the north, particularly the kingdom of Leon-Castile under Alfonso VI . Alfonso VI's ambition was to unite Iberia under his rule . The capture of Toledo by Alfonso VI in 1085 was a significant event that preceded the Battle of Zallaqa ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Historical Context"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {

                                ],
                                "text": "The battle pitted Alfonso VI, King of Castile and Galicia (r. 1077–1109), against al-Mu‘tamid Ibn ‘Abbad, Prince of the emirate of Seville (r. 1061–1091) . Facing increasing pressure from Alfonso VI, al-Mu'tamid Ibn Abbad sought assistance from the Almoravids, a powerful Berber dynasty from North Africa . The Almoravids, led by Yusuf ibn Tashufin, responded to the call and crossed the Strait of Gibraltar into al-Andalus ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Zallaqa resulted in a significant defeat for Alfonso VI . The Almoravid victory checked the advance of the Christian kingdoms and marked a turning point in the Reconquista . Following the battle, Alfonso VI entrusted El Cid with the protection of Valencia . El Cid, who had previously served the Muslim king of Zaragoza, ruled Valencia from 1092 to 1099, defending it against the Almoravids . The Almoravids' intervention had a profound impact on religious tolerance and the treatment of minorities in al-Andalus . The years 1086-1094 were a time of political transition in Muslim Spain ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Battle and its Aftermath"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-96481-2_9",
                                    "https://scholar.archive.org/work/xrdmjj5ltvewfcjhvmhs66ja74/access/wayback/https://collections.lib.utah.edu/dl_files/98/72/98723191318b34224000de8c5fffdca851e2bd56.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Historical accounts of the Battle of Zallaqa are found in various sources, including poems composed shortly after the battle and historical accounts from later periods . The study of the Taifa Kings era (1013-1086) and the role of the 'ulama' (Muslim religious and legal scholars) provides further context for understanding the events leading up to the battle . Contemporary historians often view the Andalusi ulama as a homogeneous group, but this view is challenged by dividing them into \"mosque ulama\" and \"palace ulama\" . Most historical sources for the Taifa kings era are narrated from the point of view of a subset of the mosque ulama who opposed the Taifa kings and supported their overthrow . The battle is also examined through the lens of mythos and logos, analyzing how poetic and historical narratives shaped its memory ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Historiographical Perspectives"

After the defeat at Zallaqa, Alfonso VI accepted El Cid again as a vassal, entrusting him with the protection of Valencia . El Cid's actions are related to the broader context of the Christian-Muslim conflicts, including the Battle of Zallaqa ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Almohad Empire, or al-Muwahhidūn, was founded in the mid-12th century . The movement originated among the Maṣmūda tribes of the High Atlas Mountains in Morocco . Ibn Tūmart, a Maṣmūda Berber tribesman, was considered the mahdī by the Almohads . He preached the Almohad doctrine from 1117 until his death in 1130 . Ibn Tūmart was born around 1081 in Igli, a village in the Hargha tribe . He traveled to Cordoba in 1106 to study Zahirite doctrine and subsequently to the Mashreq, including Baghdad, where he studied Ash'arite theology under the influence of al-Ghazali . Upon his return to the Maghreb in 1117, he preached against the decadent lifestyles of the urban population and was expelled from Bejaïa for his extremism ."

By 1172, the Almohads controlled al-Andalus, the Maghreb, and much of Ifriqiya . The Almohads promoted the Maṣmūda language, alongside Arabic . They were known for urban architecture, especially minarets, and patronized the arts and sciences ."

They saw themselves as a renewed form of early Islam, following the model of the prophet Muhammad . The Almohad rule involved a centralization of power under the Caliph . The Almohad administration employed a bureaucracy and a formalization of legal and administrative procedures . The Almohads used the title of Caliph, which signified their claim to universal authority over the dār al-islām . They emphasized order and used the term \"troupeau\" (ra‘iyya) and the term amr (order) in relation to the Almohad exercise of power ."

They integrated Arab tribes, which may have contributed to the empire's longevity . The Almohads implemented a major monetary reform affecting the shape, inscriptions, and metrology of the coins . They rejected recognition of the Abbasid caliphs in coins and included a reference to the Mahdi ."

                                "text": "The Almohad Revolution, or ثورة الموحدين ضد المرابطين, was a significant event in the history of the medieval Maghrib and al-Andalus, marking the end of Almoravid rule and the rise of the Almohad Caliphate . The Almoravids, a Berber dynasty, had unified al-Andalus and parts of North Africa, but faced increasing challenges to their legitimacy . The Almohad movement emerged as a religious reform movement that opposed the Almoravids ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Ibn Tūmart, the founder of the Almohad movement, initiated religious reforms that challenged the prevailing Malikite orthodoxy . He criticized the Almoravids' interpretations of the Qur'an and their reliance on Maliki scholars . Ibn Tumart introduced a new religious doctrine around 1121, centered on Tawhid (the oneness of God) . He embraced various theological currents and claimed to be the Mahdi . The Almohads aimed to re-establish the link between the Muslim community and the Qur'an and the Prophet's example . They presented themselves as restorers of the original ideals and values of the Prophet's community ."

The Almohads considered the mosques they encountered in conquered territories to be polluted and in need of purification ."

Ibn Tumart himself died three months later . Despite this setback, the Almohad movement continued under the leadership of Abd al-Mu'min, who succeeded Ibn Tumart ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Almohad Revolution brought about significant changes in the political, religious, and cultural landscape of the medieval Maghrib and al-Andalus . The Almohads' emphasis on religious reform, centralized administration, and military expansion left a lasting impact on the region . However, their policies also led to persecution of religious minorities and ultimately contributed to their own decline . The Almohad period saw changes in the world of scholarship in al-Andalus, with an attempt to break with the 'Maliki' tradition . The Almohad revolution can be seen as the culmination of a longer process of intellectual, religious, and political emancipation of the Western Muslim world ."

                                "text": "Al-Andalus, the term used by Muslims to refer to the Iberian Peninsula, was established following the Muslim conquest in 711 AD . This conquest, led by Arab and Berber troops, brought an end to Visigothic rule in Hispania . The Muslim forces, under the leadership of figures like Tariq ibn Ziyad, gained control over most of the peninsula, with the exception of the mountainous regions in the north and northwest where Christian kingdoms emerged . By the 11th century, the majority of the population in Al-Andalus were Arabic-speaking Muslims . The Christian population diminished through emigration, deportation, and conversion, while Jewish communities generally flourished, although periods of forced conversion did occur ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Umayyad dynasty, after being overthrown in the Levant, established an independent emirate in Al-Andalus in 756 CE . Cordoba became the capital, first of the Umayyad emirate (756–929) and then of the Umayyad caliphate (929–1031) . During this period, Cordoba became a major center of wealth and culture in Europe, flourishing due to agriculture and trade . However, the Umayyad Caliphate was abolished in 1031, leading to the emergence of smaller Taifa kingdoms . These Taifa kingdoms, ruled by local notables, were militarily weak and forced to pay tribute to the advancing Christian kingdoms . The fall of Toledo to the Christians in 1085 prompted the Taifa kings to seek aid from the Almoravids ."

                                "text": "The Almoravids and Almohads nurtured specifically Islamic thought and feeling due to their religious outlook . The Almohad regime's rule in Al-Andalus had a significant social impact . The Almohads are characterized as narrow-minded forces that contributed to the end of the culture of tolerance in Al-Andalus . The progressive growth of Christian kingdoms led to the domination of territories occupied by the Muslim Andalusi population . The Andalusi population faced the choice of staying in their homes or emigrating and undergoing forced exile . The memory of the Andalusi refugees is described as a reminder of a lost era of tolerance ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Almohad period is part of the broader history of Al-Andalus, which has been subject to various interpretations and myths . In the last two decades, the Spanish press's portrayal of the Muslim world shifted from unsympathetic to enthusiastic . This change is partly due to immigration trends, control over oil resources, and relativism in Western discourses towards the Third World . In Spain, a significant internal element is the mass-media's reinvention of a mythical al-Andalus as a tolerant and pluralistic society . This idealized interpretation of seven centuries of Muslim presence in the Iberian Peninsula is based on ignorance and distorts the historical record . The manipulation of the myth of al-Andalus, regardless of intent, has ideological and political implications ."

            {
                "article_title": "The Almohad Defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 608,
                        "start": 608
                    },
                    "milady": {
                        "end": 1212,
                        "start": 1212

                "event_name": "هزيمة الموحدين في معركة العقاب",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/ar/issue002/pages/art03.aspx",
                                    "https://www.torrossa.com/gs/resourceProxy?an=4896254&publisher=FZ1335"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Almohad Caliphate, during its expansion in the western Mediterranean, made critical strategic errors that ultimately contributed to its defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa (معركة العقاب) . The Almohads expanded eastward, opening a front with Arab tribes in Africa and the Banu Ghaniya in the Balearic Islands . This focus on the eastern front led to a neglect of the northern front in al-Andalus, which proved to be a more significant threat . Azz al-Din Jassus argues that this strategic misdirection was a key factor in the Almohad defeat . The Almohads lacked a balanced geo-political view and failed to recognize the greater danger posed by the Christian kingdoms in the north . Francisco García Fitz's work examines Castilian-Leonese politics in the face of the Almohad empire, highlighting the context leading up to this pivotal battle ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Strategic Miscalculations"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/ar/issue002/pages/art03.aspx"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Almohad defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa (معركة العقاب) had catastrophic consequences for both al-Andalus and Morocco . The Christian Reconquista capitalized on the Almohad weakness, seizing the Balearic Islands . Furthermore, major cities such as Cordoba, Valencia, Murcia, Jaen, and Seville fell to the Christians during this period . The defeat marked a turning point in the history of al-Andalus, accelerating the decline of Muslim rule in the Iberian Peninsula ."
                            }

                                    "https://www.torrossa.com/gs/resourceProxy?an=4896254&publisher=FZ1335"
                                ],
                                "text": "The defeat of the Almohads at Las Navas de Tolosa occurred within a broader context of political and military interactions between the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa . The book \"Relaciones políticas y guerra : la experiencia castellano-leonesa frente al Islam : siglos XI-XIII\" explores these relations from the 11th to the 13th centuries . The Almohad Empire was a key player in this dynamic . The defeat also impacted later events, such as the defeat of the Portuguese by the Moors in Alcácer Quibir, which contributed to the rise of Portuguese Sebastianism, a form of royal messianism . Jacqueline Hermann's article discusses royal messianism in the Iberian world between the 14th and 16th centuries, tracing its roots back to the Middle Ages and its development in the Modern Period . The defeat at Alcácer Quibir created a specific political context that fueled messianic expectations ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "The First Moroccan Crisis, also known as the Tangier Crisis, unfolded between 1905 and 1906 and centered on the struggle for control over the Sultanate of Morocco . This crisis is considered a key moment in geopolitical confrontation among major world powers . Morocco's strategic and economic importance attracted the attention of European powers, including France, Germany, Great Britain, and Spain . The crisis was an outgrowth of events extending back to the Congress of Berlin . By the beginning of the 20th century, Morocco was the only independent state in the Maghreb ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://etd.ohiolink.edu/acprod/odb_etd/ws/send_file/send?accession=osu1422543485&disposition=inline",

                                ],
                                "text": "France sought to establish a protectorate in Morocco, a move that was formalized by the Treaty of Fez in 1912 . However, France's ambitions were complicated by existing agreements and the interests of other European powers . The Madrid Convention of 1880 guaranteed equal economic access to Morocco for all signatory powers . The Entente Cordiale, signed between England and France on April 8, 1904, settled colonial disputes, with France recognizing British occupation of Egypt in exchange for British permission for France to institute reforms in Morocco . Secret articles of the Entente Cordiale contemplated the eventual partitioning of Morocco between France and Spain ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Context"

                                ],
                                "text": "Germany, under Kaiser Wilhelm II, opposed French influence in Morocco . Germany's grievances included ignored economic interests, a blow to national prestige, and apprehension over the Anglo-French agreement . Germany's total tonnage of ships calling at Moroccan ports in 1905 was larger than France's, highlighting German economic interests . Germany hoped to obtain the port of Casablanca through the Conference of Algeciras . Germany intervened in Morocco partly to test the relations between England and France . The Russo-Japanese War weakened Russia, leading Germany to act opportunistically in Morocco ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "Emperor Wilhelm II visited Tangier on March 31, 1905, to support the Sultan of Morocco and challenge the legality of the Anglo-French agreement . Germany argued that the Anglo-French agreement violated the Madrid Convention of 1880, which guaranteed equal economic access to Morocco for all signatory powers . The Kaiser presented himself as the guarantor of the Sultan's independence and sovereignty . This act triggered the First Moroccan Crisis . Chancellor Bernhard von Bülow played a crucial role in guiding German policy during the crisis, convincing the Kaiser to visit Tangiers ."

                                ],
                                "text": "President Theodore Roosevelt of the United States played a role in the crisis . In January 1905, von Bulow inquired whether the United States would be affected by French administrative reforms in Morocco . On March 6, 1905, Sternburg asked Roosevelt to join Germany in maintaining the open door in Morocco . On April 5, the Kaiser insisted on a conference to decide the Moroccan question, citing German interests and dignity . By May 13, the Kaiser threatened war if support for a conference was not obtained . In late April/early May, Roosevelt attempted to bring England and Germany together, but was accused of being under the Kaiser's influence . On April 22, England pledged strong opposition to Germany acquiring a port on the Moorish coast ."
                            },

                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p2",

                                ],
                                "text": "The French Cabinet crisis, resulting in Foreign Minister Théophile Delcassé's resignation, occurred because of the conference issue . Delcassé failed to secure Germany's assent to the French move on Morocco, a major diplomatic blunder . Delcassé opposed any international conference, while Germany threatened war if its demands were not met . Delcassé believed Germany's limited power projection capabilities made its threats less credible, while Prime Minister Maurice Rouvier believed Germany was resolved and capable of punishing France . France agreed to the conference on June 25 after being pressured by the Kaiser via Roosevelt . On July 8, an agreement was reached where Germany pledged to pursue no goal at the Conference that would compromise France's legitimate interests or be contrary to French treaty rights ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p3",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://etd.ohiolink.edu/acprod/odb_etd/ws/send_file/send?accession=osu1422543485&disposition=inline",
                                    "https://scholar.archive.org/work/ctycv5r74bhkfkmsabt3incsee/access/wayback/http://dynamiques-internationales.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Loewener-DI10-final-1.pdf",

                                    "https://zaguan.unizar.es/record/108760/files/TAZ-TFG-2021-4202.pdf?version=1"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Algeciras Conference concluded on April 7, 1906, granting France significant prerogatives in Morocco . The conference aimed to resolve Franco-German antagonism over Morocco . Henry White was chosen as the principal United States delegate for his diplomatic experience and his sympathy towards the Anglo-French . At the first meeting of the Conference on January 16, 1906, the Duke of Almodovar (Spain) was elected president . By February 7, 1906, there was complete agreement on the matter of tax reforms at the conference . On February 3, Revoil proposed to Von Radowitz that the mandate for the police be shared with Spain as a concession, a French strategy to enlist U.S intervention . On February 4, White expressed support for the Franco-Spanish proposal, stating it met the maximum equity and logic required of France . On February 6, White wrote to Root that France would not yield on the matter of the police . On February 8, Von Radowitz talked with White and Venosta again, proposing that the Sultan have control of the police but with instructors from three secondary powers, a plan White refused to endorse . On February 13, Germany sent a telegram indicating they would rather disrupt the conference than retreat further . From February 14-15, White and Revoil had conversations that resulted in the White-Revoil formula, with the recommendation for Roosevelt to recommend a compromise to the Kaiser . On February 16, White recommended that Germany either accept the French proposals or end the Conference . On March 7, Roosevelt sent a letter to the Kaiser urging acceptance of Roosevelt's recommendations . On March 8, the Austrian delegate proposed a plan to assign French police to certain ports and Spanish police to others, with Casablanca under an Inspector General . On the 14th of March 1906, a French ministerial crisis ended and the Kaiser sent a stronger telegram to Roosevelt denouncing the French . On the 17th of March, Root informed White that The US stood for freedom of commerce and a limited control by France and Spain through a multi-lateral mandate . Roosevelt made a public statement praising Germany and it's leaders on April 12 1906 ."

                                "text": "The First Moroccan Crisis highlighted the conflict between Germany's desire for international recognition and its actual status in the eyes of other great powers . The crisis also played a role in the polarization of international relations leading up to World War I . Some historians view the crisis as a major confrontation between Great Powers over a sultanate . The crisis also contributed to the British \"continental commitment,\" with joint British-French staff talks taking place from December 1905 to May 1906 ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "The crisis can be interpreted through various theoretical lenses. One perspective suggests that Germany's actions were primarily driven by a need to defend its identity and prestige, which it felt were being ignored by France's actions in Morocco, rather than by purely material or strategic considerations . An alternative interpretation uses an incomplete information game model to explain the actions of players in the early stages of the crisis, as well as British support of France, France's firm stance, and Germany's decision to seek a conference ."

A counter-narrative emphasizes agency in the periphery and explores the relationship between empire, emerging Moroccan classes, and the expansion of European capital . Moroccan protest and resistance were widespread and persistent throughout the period 1900-1912 . French colonial policy coded Moroccan resistance as traditional anarchy and xenophobia, ignoring its political meaning ."

                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://history.hanover.edu/hhr/23/hhr2023complete.pdf#page=65",
                                    "https://rightwiki.org/index.php?title=Agadir",
                                    "https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/historical-journal/article/viii-commercial-interests-and-german-diplomacy-in-the-agadir-crisis/7197601E08C4D15B162460885E349BB1",

                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315633916-8/spirit-recognition-foreign-policy-richard-ned-lebow"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Agadir Crisis, also known as the Second Moroccan Crisis, occurred in 1911 and exposed the growing tensions between France and Germany, foreshadowing the outbreak of World War I . The crisis stemmed from long-standing imperial rivalries between European powers, particularly France and Germany, over Morocco . Germany's position among the great powers of Europe had endured setbacks since 1890, with Russia becoming an ally of France in 1894 and Great Britain signing an agreement with France in 1904 . In 1907, Russia and Great Britain also came to terms . The Anglo-French Entente of 1904 settled the future of Morocco, with Great Britain agreeing that France might establish a protectorate there . Germany, a signatory of the Madrid Convention of 1880, was not officially notified or consulted about the French protectorate in Morocco . This contributed to Morocco becoming a symbol of Germany's declining prestige ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9780203624586-6/entente-cordiale-began-john-keiger",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9780203624586-7/german-threat-christopher-andrew-paul-vallet"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Entente Cordiale of April 8, 1904, between Britain and France, was a settlement of colonial disputes, with France recognizing British interests in Egypt in exchange for British recognition of French interests in Morocco . As French ambassador Paul Cambon stated, \"we give you Egypt in exchange for Morocco\" . This agreement laid the groundwork for a closer relationship between the two nations leading up to World War I ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p2",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://publication.npru.ac.th/bitstream/123456789/1466/1/npru_211.pdf",
                                    "https://www.ebsco.com/research-starters/history/tangier-crisis"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Tangier Crisis of 1905 was a significant diplomatic conflict between Germany and France over the status of Morocco . German Emperor Wilhelm II visited Tangier on March 31, 1905, asserting support for Moroccan sovereignty and challenging French control . This action stemmed from German concerns about French expansionism and its agreements with Britain and Spain . The crisis escalated as Germany called for an international conference, leading to the Algeciras Conference in 1906, where France's claims were largely upheld, isolating Germany . The Tangier Crisis reinforced the Anglo-French alliance and contributed to the formation of the Triple Entente ."
                            }

The deployment of the Panther was also intended to intimidate the British navy, as Germany sought to challenge British naval dominance . Hermann Wilberg, the German sales representative sent to provide the pretext for intervention, arrived three days after the Panther . The German ships Berlin and Panther alternated off the port of Agadir during the crisis ."

                            },
                            {

                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-70800-8_2",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781003019374-9/spain-north-african-sara-mehlmer"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Spanish-Moroccan War, also known as the War of Tetouan (الحرب الإسبانية-المغربية حرب تطوان), erupted in 1859, rooted in a complex history of Spanish-North African relations and Spain's desire to assert its influence in the region . Centuries of Christian-Muslim contact had left a cultural legacy in Spain, but also contributed to perceptions of Spain as backward . Spain's declaration of war in October 1859 was partly motivated by a desire to emulate the influence of France and Great Britain in Africa . Some in Spain saw the war as a new colonial project during a time of imperial collapse, offering a chance to vindicate Spain's perceived derision by north-western European powers and providing a sense of unity during a period of socio-political disunity ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/acrh/1805",

                                ],
                                "text": "The immediate trigger for the war was a border dispute near Ceuta, one of Spain's long-held presidios in North Africa . The Anyera tribe destroyed a boundary stone, leading to Spain's declaration of war on October 22, 1859 . This incident served as a pretext for Spain to pursue its broader colonial ambitions . The Spanish government, led by Leopoldo O'Donnell, sought to use a military victory to strengthen national sentiment and quell internal political instability ."

Tactical superiority and the discipline of Spanish soldiers contributed to victories at Castillejos, M'nuel River, and Cabo Negro, securing the Tetuan valley . The capture of Tetouan on February 6, 1860, marked a turning point and demonstrated Spain's capacity to seize an important enclave ."

It defined Ceuta and Melilla's borders, ceded Ifni to Spain, set a war indemnity of 20 million duros (400,000,000 reales or 100 million pesetas), and allowed Spain to occupy Tetouan as collateral until the debt was settled . Morocco struggled to make the indemnity payments, leading to increased taxes, a loan from Great Britain, and eventually Spanish control of customs revenues in several Moroccan cities from 1862 to 1884 . The war cost Spain 236 million reales ."

                "event_name": "الحرب الإنجليزية-المغربية",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://escholarship.org/content/qt0029s2pm/qt0029s2pm.pdf",
                                    "https://etheses.whiterose.ac.uk/id/eprint/17412/7/MA%20by%20Research%20dissertation%20Thomas%20Collins.pdf",

                                    "https://www.soas.ac.uk/sites/default/files/2022-06/03%20Orientalism%20Occidentalism%20and%20Anglo-Moroccan%20relations%20in%20the%2016th%20and%2017th%20centuries%20a%20case%20study%20in%20historicising%20concepts%20of%20discourse%20file58311.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Anglo-Moroccan relations date back to the 13th century, with an envoy from King John of England seeking military assistance from Sultan Mohamed al-Naṣīr against France . Mercantile and trading opportunities became noticeable around the 16th century . The first known British trading voyages to Morocco occurred in 1551, driven by interest in gold, saltpetre, and sugar . James Aldy's account of this voyage provides insight into early British experiences in Barbary . England and Morocco found common ground against Spain, with Morocco providing saltpetre for English gunpowder in exchange for arms . Elizabeth I chartered the Barbary Company in Morocco, which produced crucial economic and political benefits for England . The Barbary Company was formed in 1585 under the Earl of Leicester to foster trade relations . In 1583, Lord Burghley advised Queen Elizabeth on the suitability of an alliance with Morocco ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://brill.com/view/journals/jemh/12/1/article-p55_3.xml",
                                    "https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/161459317.pdf",
                                    "https://escholarship.org/content/qt0029s2pm/qt0029s2pm.pdf",
                                    "https://revista-anglo-saxonica.org/articles/22/files/submission/proof/22-1-68-1-10-20200110.pdf",
                                    "https://revista-anglo-saxonica.org/en/articles/10.5334/as.22",
                                    "https://spanish.wikibrief.org/wiki/Protestantism_and_Islam",
                                    "https://www.soas.ac.uk/sites/default/files/2022-06/03%20Orientalism%20Occidentalism%20and%20Anglo-Moroccan%20relations%20in%20the%2016th%20and%2017th%20centuries%20a%20case%20study%20in%20historicising%20concepts%20of%20discourse%20file58311.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Sa’adī Sultans ‘Abd al-Mālek (1575–1578) and Aḥmed al-Manṣūr (1578–1603) exchanged diplomatic letters with Queen Elizabeth I (1558–1603) to strengthen mutual diplomacies and issue decrees favoring English merchants . Elizabeth I engaged in diplomatic relations with the Barbary states, particularly Morocco, selling arms and supplies in exchange for sugar . The alliance grew stronger under Aḥmed al-Manṣūr, particularly after the defeat of the Portuguese in 1578 at the Battle of Alcazar . This alliance granted England unprecedented protectionist privileges at sea, while Morocco gained substantial power and diplomatic recognition . England’s victory over the Spanish Armada in 1588 changed al-Mansur’s impression of Elizabeth and prompted him to propose a joint attack against Spain . Drake's expedition against Lisbon in 1589 was planned with the expectation of Moroccan support, which ultimately did not materialize . Moroccan ships possibly aided the English at Cadiz in 1596, according to intelligence from the Fugger merchants . In 1596, Elizabeth’s ships and soldiers, along with ships and supplies from al-Mansur, were victorious in their attack on Cadiz . Morocco provided logistical assistance to the English attack on Cadiz in 1596 ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p2",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://escholarship.org/content/qt0029s2pm/qt0029s2pm.pdf",

                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315234281-24/ambassador-reception-moroccan-embassy-london-1637%E2%80%931638-pageantry-maritime-politics",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315589923-3/two-faced-muslim-early-modern-imagination-imtiaz-habib"
                                ],
                                "text": "Elizabeth I and her government considered a formal alliance with Morocco, proposed by Sultan Ahmad al-Mansur, but it was never consummated . Al-Mansur proposed a military venture against Spain to Queen Elizabeth . Elizabeth's disinclination towards the military venture against Spain was a negotiation tactic for English profitability . In 1600, Abd el-Ouahed ben Messaoud visited London to confirm the collaboration between Elizabeth I and Ahmad Al-Mansur . Al-Mansur sent another delegation in 1600 to England, but they disagreed on jointly invading Spain . In 1601, al-Mansur proposed an attack on Spanish holdings in the Americas to Elizabeth, which she rejected . In 1602, al-Mansur signed a military agreement with Spain against their joint rival, the Ottoman Empire ."

The King of England viewed North African pirate citadels as a hindrance to commercial expansion and an affront to national pride . The Sultan of Morocco considered the pirate citadels a threat to his regional pre-eminence, viewing them as rebels or forward operating bases of the Ottoman Empire . In 1626, the Moriscos of Salé concluded a treaty with British emissary John Harrison to secure independence . Charles I refused to ratify Harrison’s treaty with the Moriscos of Salé .                                 "text": "The First Barbary War, also known as the Tripolitan War, was a naval conflict fought between the United States and Tripoli (present-day Libya) from 1801 to 1805 . This war marked the first instance of American military power projection across the world . The roots of the conflict lay in the practice of Barbary piracy, where states in North Africa—Morocco, Algiers, Tunis, and Tripoli—engaged in attacking merchant vessels in the Mediterranean Sea, seizing their goods, and enslaving their crews . These Barbary pirates, supported by Pashas and Deys, demanded tribute from European and American vessels in exchange for safe passage . European powers, including England and France, often paid annual tribute as a form of 'insurance' ."
                            },

In 1786, the U.S. government agreed to pay tribute to the Barbary states to stop attacks on American ships . By 1797, the United States had paid out $1.25 million in tribute . The Naval Act of 1794, passed on March 27, established the first US Navy to combat these attacks and demands for money . The USS Constitution was the first naval vessel to complete construction ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Iberian Peninsula has been a site of conflict since ancient times. During the Second Punic War, Rome sent a senatorial commission to Carthage in 219 BCE following the conquest of Sagunt, Rome's ally in Iberia . In 218 BCE, a consular army was dispatched to Northeastern Spain to counter Hannibal's advance on Italy, marking the beginning of a broader conflict . A large portion of Spain was under Carthaginian control due to the Barcids during this period . The Senate decided to vigorously pursue the war in Spain, creating a series of extraordinary proconsulates in 217 BCE . From 218 to 197 BCE, the command structure in Spain shifted between one and two 'summi imperatores' (supreme commanders) appointed through senatorial decrees and popular laws . The Romans established a network of garrisons in Spain to secure the hinterland, facilitate recruitment, and provision armies ."

                                "text": "The War of the Spanish Succession (1701-1714) involved Spain as a key territory contested by European powers . This conflict stemmed from the death of the childless Charles II of Spain and the subsequent struggle for the Spanish throne . France, under Louis XIV, sought to secure the throne for his grandson, Philip of Anjou, while other European powers, including Austria, England, and the Dutch Republic, opposed French dominance and supported the Habsburg claim . The war was fought across Europe, including significant battles in Spain, Italy, and the Netherlands . The conflict concluded with the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713, which recognized Philip of Anjou as King Philip V of Spain but with significant limitations on Spanish power and territorial concessions to other European powers . A louse-borne typhus outbreak occurred in Douai, France, between 1710 and 1712 during the War of Spanish Succession, potentially introduced by Spanish soldiers ."

                                    "https://ap1.sib.uc.pt/bitstream/10316.2/39677/1/presentation_de_l_ouvrage_de_jose.pdf",

                                ],
                                "text": "Mazagan, now known as El Jadida, was founded by King Emmanuel of Portugal in 1514 . The toponym 'Mazagan' is possibly of Berber origin, with forms such as 'Mazighan' appearing in texts from the 11th and 12th centuries . Duarte Pacheco Pereira described Mazagan around the beginning of the 16th century, noting the location of a destroyed city . In the summer of 1514, construction of the castle of Mazagan accelerated under Portuguese military protection . Some strategists questioned the need for a fortress at Mazagan given the fortress being built at Azamor . Mazagan began as a small protectorate of the Portuguese crown in 1486 . After the conquest of Azamor in 1513, King Manuel I ordered the transformation of Mazagan into a bastioned fortress to protect the Carreira da Índia . In 1541, Mazagan was transformed into a grand fortress city, considered the first 'ideal city' of the Renaissance built outside of Europe ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://openarchive.icomos.org/id/eprint/1336/1/Masterthesis_PD_Lavies.pdf",

                                ],
                                "text": "Around 1540, the building of the bastioned fortress of Mazagan in North Africa marked a turning point in Portuguese fortification . The hiring of an Italian engineer played a major role in the construction of the Mazagan fortress . The experimental process and knowledge transfer involved in the construction of Mazagan went beyond a simple technical delivery from the center to the periphery . In 1541, Benedetto da Ravenna inspected Portuguese cities in Morocco, including Septa, Tangier, and Mazagan . Benedetto da Ravenna's plan for Mazagan is considered the first perfect European bulwarked fortification . In 1541, Benedetto da Ravenna and Miguel de Arruda visited Mazagão to modernise the fortifications . Francisco de Holanda drew the initial model for the fortifications at Mazagão applying the bastion system, though he never visited Mazagão himself . The construction of angled bastions in Mazagão started in 1541, potentially impacting discussions on fort design ."

The cistern in Mazagan was built between 1541 and 1547 . The fortress in Mazagão resisted local armies until 1769, at which point it was abandoned due to a long siege and the inability to maintain a garrison ."

Attacks occurred in 1517, and in 1521, Portugues and Moors perished under the walls . In 1525, the King of Fez laid siege to Mazagan . In March 1561, there was a battle after the son of the Sharif demanded the keys to the fortress . In 1562, Agostinho de Gavy de Mendonça's book \"Historia do famoso cerco...\" describes a siege of Mazagan . In 1562, during the defense of Mazagan by Mulay Abdallah's forces, the poem 'De bello Mazagonico' was created, portraying Saadi rulers negatively . Antonio Lopes' poem 'De bello Mazagonico' drew inspiration from Aeschylus' 'The Persians' in its depiction of Muslim rulers ."

                                "text": "Mazagan was the last Portuguese city in the Maghreb, abandoned in 1769 . Mazagan was the only Portuguese establishment remaining on the Atlantic coast of Morocco . The abandonment of Mazagan was decided in January 1769 by the Marquis de Pombal and the King of Portugal . On March 11, 1769, the Portuguese evacuated Mazagan . On March 11, 1769, the entire population of Mazagan was forced to abandon the city and return to Lisbon . On March 1, 1769, a fleet of 14 ships arrived from Lisbon with instructions for the abandonment of the city . The fleet had departed from Lisbon on February 3, 1769 . A truce was established with the besieging forces on March 9, 1769 . The population of Mazagan was told that the abandonment was for their own safety from the 'barbarity of the Moors' ."

                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "The population of Mazagan at the time of evacuation was approximately 2100 people, under the governance of Dinis Gregorio de Melo e Castro Mendonça . Approximately 2,100 people, comprising 460 families, 31 single soldiers, and 4 priests, sailed for Lisbon . Women, children, invalids, and the sick were evacuated first . Sacred images, silverware, and church ornaments were prioritized during the evacuation . Carriages were burned, iron cannons were thrown into the sea, and walls and buildings were exploded to leave only ruins . On March 8, 1769, embarkation occurred through the 'Porte de la Mer' . The Portuguese destroyed a bastion in Mazagan as they withdrew, killing hundreds of Muslim soldiers . In 1769, there were approximately 200 horses in Mazagan . The city's fortifications had walls that were twelve meters wide . In 1769, Mazagan had five churches, eight small chapels, and fifteen priests . Colonel Carlos Julião, a military officer who participated in the 1769 mission, recalled being part of the expedition against the 'contagious society' of Mazagan ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p2",

                                "text": "The 2100 evacuees were intended to help populate the Amazon . The abandonment of Mazagan was part of a larger plan by Pombal to secure Portuguese interests in the Amazon, seeing the city as a drain on resources . The Portuguese community of Mazagan was deported to the Amazon . On March 11, 1769, the Portuguese community left Mazagan on 12 ships for Lisbon under the order of King Joseph and the Marquis of Pombal . In 1769, 371 families (2000 people) embarked from Lisbon to Para on nine ships on September 15 . They arrived in Belém do Para in early January 1770 . From 1772, the inhabitants of Mazagan were gradually transferred to Nova Mazagão . The Mazagan population was relocated to Vila Nova de Mazagão in the Amazon region of Brazil in 1771 after a delay and poor treatment in Lisbon . In 1775, five years after their arrival to Brazil, there were still 68 Mazagan families awaiting relocation in Belém . The new city of Mazagão in Brazil was designed by Domingo Sambuceti and officially founded in 1771 ."

Mazagan became El-Mahduma ('The Destroyed') and remained empty for 50 years . Later Moroccan rulers worked to rebuild Mazagan, eventually renaming it El-Jadida ('new' or 'renewed') . Around 1820, Jewish merchants requested permission to settle there, and the city was rebuilt and renamed El Jadida ('The New') . In 1821, the city was renamed El Jadida (the New) . In 1822, Alawite rulers commissioned the rebuilding of the connection to the mainland and new city walls in El-Jadida . Christian families were permitted to settle in El-Jadida and practice their religion . The arrival of a Jewish community in the mid-19th century contributed to the cosmopolitan image of El-Jadida ."

The Plan Azur aimed to create six new coastal resorts, but only Mediterrania Saïdia (opened in 2009) and Mazagan (opened in spring 2010) were realized . The Mazagan resort is located about an hour south of Casablanca and is served by Casablanca's airport ."

                "article_title": "The First Melilla Campaign: Conflict and Colonialism in 1909",

                    "hijry": {

                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://encyclopedia.1914-1918-online.net/pdf/1914-1918-Online-spain-2015-03-20.pdf",
                                    "https://helda.helsinki.fi/server/api/core/bitstreams/9d7fdd8e-7d4f-441d-9bb7-66f629a7b252/content",
                                    "https://ifc.dpz.es/recursos/publicaciones/40/07/03sanchez.pdf",
                                    "https://shs.hal.science/halshs-01170449v1/file/09_Eduard%20RODRIGUEZ-MARTIN.pdf",
                                    "https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-political-science-review/article/spanish-interests-in-morocco/EEE5804F429A37862FE66107FAD2BF15"
                                ],
                                "text": "The First Melilla Campaign, also known as the Melilla War or the Gurugú War, took place in 1909 . This conflict was rooted in Spain's long-standing presence in Morocco, dating back to the Middle Ages . By 1911, Spain was the only foreign power with a foothold on Moroccan soil, possessing the cities of Melilla and Ceuta, as well as the island presidios of Penon de Velez de Gomera, the Alhucemas, and the Zaffarines . Melilla, a Spanish territory of 12 km2 located in northeastern Morocco, had been under Spanish sovereignty since 1497 . It initially served as a prison colony for nearly four centuries before its economic and political transformation began in the second half of the 19th century . Melilla was declared a free port in 1863 ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://olh.openlibhums.org/article/4670/galley/23245/view/",
                                    "https://shs.hal.science/halshs-01170449v1/file/09_Eduard%20RODRIGUEZ-MARTIN.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Algeciras Conference in 1906 established French supremacy over Morocco but acknowledged Spanish influence in northern territories . This led to the implementation of the Spanish Protectorate of Morocco in 1912 in the Rif, Ifni, and Tarfaya regions . However, Ceuta and Melilla were not included in the Algeciras convention, as Spain considered its rights over these territories to predate the Protectorate ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "Since 1909, Spanish forces had been expanding from Melilla towards the Rif heartland . By 1921, they had almost reached Alhucemas Bay . The 1909 Melilla campaign was influenced by the economic opportunity opened by the protective mission of the Spanish army in Morocco awarded by the Algeciras Conference . Mining resources became a priority for Spanish oligarchs, which prompted an economic penetration into a region of Morocco controlled by a series of tribes ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [

                                ],
                                "text": "The construction of a Spanish fort at Sidi Ouriach was a key factor leading to the conflict . The Rif tribes petitioned against the fort's construction because it interfered with their mosque and cemetery . General Margallo threatened punishment to anyone who attempted to interrupt the work . The Kabyles opposed the construction of the fort, perceiving its strategic importance for controlling their movements . The fort's proximity to a shrine frequented by Moorish women was also cited as a cause of the outbreak ."

The Spanish government reinforced its forces with 40,000 reserves due to the conflict near Melilla in 1909 ."

                                "text": "The First Melilla Campaign marked the beginning of air medical transportation in Spain . The Spanish military aviation was a pioneer in Morocco, and Commander Mariano Gómez Ulla played a crucial role in the urgent evacuation of the wounded ."

The tanks experienced a less than successful debut due to factors such as the separation of infantry and tanks, faulty ammunition, and lack of coordinated training .                                     "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1975_num_20_1_1330"
                                ],
                                "text": "The phrase \"صراعات سلالية بعد وفاة إسماعيل\" translates to \"Dynastic Conflicts Following the Death of Ismail.\" This article synthesizes information from various sources to explore instances of succession struggles and internal power conflicts that occurred after the death of rulers named Ismail in different historical contexts. These include, but are not limited to, the Alaouite dynasty in Morocco after the death of Moulay Ismail in 1727 , the Safavid dynasty after the death of Shah Ismail I in 1524 , and the rule of Khedive Ismail of Egypt, whose deposition in 1879 led to political instability . The article also examines succession issues in other dynasties, such as the Ptolemaic dynasty in Egypt , the Al Sabah dynasty in Kuwait , and the Nasrid dynasty of Granada , to provide a broader understanding of the dynamics of dynastic conflicts."
                            }

                        "subtitle": "Introduction"

                                "text": "Following the death of the Alaouite sultan Moulay Ismail in 1727, Morocco entered a period of significant instability and civil war . This period, lasting until 1757, was marked by numerous contenders vying for the throne . The possession of dynastic emblems, such as the sultan's parasol, horses, saddles, javelots, and lances, became crucial for establishing royal legitimacy . The recovery of these emblems was a primary objective for those seeking to claim the throne ."

For example, Abdelhaq Fennich controlled Salé from 1738 to 1757 , making Bab Sebta the seat of his caïdat . The people of Salé destroyed the Kasbah of the Gnaouas in 1738 in response to the actions of the guards stationed there . In 1736, Moulay ‘Abdallah was deposed by the inhabitants of Fez, and Mohammed b. ’Arbiyya was installed on the throne . The Jewish community also suffered during the thirty years of disorder following Moulay Ismail's death ."

                                "text": "Shah Ismail I, leader of the Safavids, seized Tabriz in 1501 and established Shia Islam as the official religion . Upon Ismail's death in 1524, his son Tahmasp, aged ten, became Shah . The coronation of Tahmasp I on June 2, 1524, triggered a decade-long power struggle among the Qizilbash clans . These clans, including rumlu, chamlu, stadjlu, takkalu, zolghdar, afshâr, qâdjâr, and warsāk, sought to regain influence after being sidelined since 1508-1510 . Div Sultan Rumlu initiated hostilities by murdering Jalal al-Din Mohammad Tabrizi and established a regency based on alleged testamentary dispositions of Ismail I . Sam Mirza replaced Tahmasp as governor of Khorasan . Tahmasp's brothers included Alqas Mirza (1515-1550), Sam Mirza (1517-1566), and Bahram Mirza (1517-1550) ."

                                "text": "Khedive Ismail ruled Egypt from 1863 to 1879 . He was deposed in 1879 due to financial catastrophe and international pressure . He was replaced by his son, Tawfiq Pasha . Ismail's reign saw a revival of educational and cultural institutions despite the increase in foreign debt and European pressure . A Caisse de la Dette Publique was established in 1876 due to the increase in foreign debt, leading to Franco-British control . The British occupation of Egypt began in 1882, influencing political developments following Ismail's departure . The Orabi revolution (1880-1882) was a consequence of financial problems and growing discontent in Egypt . The British occupation in 1882 led to the exile of Urabi and the restoration of Khedive Tawfiq's authority ."

                                "text": "Dynastic conflicts have been a recurring theme in various historical contexts. In the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt, the period from 163 BC to 80 BC saw internal conflicts within the royal family and the growing role of queens . Transitions of power often involved violence, and pretenders to the throne, especially those based in Cyprus, sought to conquer the throne . Ptolemy VI Philometor, Ptolemy VIII Euergetes II, Ptolemy IX Soter II, Ptolemy X Alexander, Cleopatra II, and Cleopatra III were key figures in these power struggles ."

                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/ARCO_ASSAR_2020_01_0297?tab=texte-integral",

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1975_num_20_1_1330"
                                ],
                                "text": "Dynastic conflicts following the death of a ruler have been a recurring feature of many societies throughout history. These conflicts often arise from uncertainties in succession, power struggles between different branches of the family, and external pressures from other powers . The examples of Morocco after Moulay Ismail's death, the Safavid dynasty after Ismail I's death, and Egypt after Khedive Ismail's deposition illustrate the diverse ways in which these conflicts can manifest and the significant impact they can have on the stability and development of a region . Understanding the dynamics of these conflicts provides valuable insights into the complexities of power, succession, and political stability in historical contexts ."

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/rnord_0035-2624_1990_num_72_285_4530"
                                ],
                                "text": "The French presence in Morocco intensified in the early 20th century, marked by increasing disorder and intervention . The Conference of Algeciras (January 16 to April 7, 1906) strengthened France's economic and military position in Morocco . However, internal unrest persisted, leading to the Treaty of Fez on March 30, 1912, which established the French Protectorate . This protectorate granted France administrative, political, and military control over Morocco . The actual conquest and pacification of the country took twenty-two years after the signing of the treaty . Even before the formal establishment of the protectorate, tensions were rising. The murder of Dr. Émile Mauchamp in Marrakech on March 19, 1907, served as a pretext for French military action . Hubert Lyautey used this event as justification for the French occupation of Oujda, a significant step in establishing the protectorate ."
                            }

                                "text": "On July 30, 1907, nine Europeans were massacred in Casablanca, precipitating the French decision to occupy the city . This massacre prompted the French government to send the warship 'Galilée' to protect the French consulate and French nationals . On August 5, 1907, the 'Galilée' landed a small troop of 66 men, who faced gunfire at the Porte de la Marine . This landing led to fighting and the subsequent bombardment of Casablanca . The decision to bombard the city was met with criticism from other powers and members of the French parliament . A French expeditionary force was concentrated at Oran and escorted to Casablanca by warships . The expeditionary force, consisting of 2,000 men under General Drude, landed in Casablanca on August 7, 1907, at noon, replacing the marines . The VI/1er RE (Foreign Legion) also landed on August 7 to defend against attacks from the Chaouia tribes . The French bombardment of Casablanca is depicted in the postcard 'La France au Maroc', showing the carnage ."

                                "text": "Following the bombardment, Casablanca came under French control . The French were responsible for maintaining order in the city after the 1907 riots . The French occupation of Morocco, including Casablanca, was interrupted by World War I (1914-1918) but resumed methodically in 1920 . The French faced resistance in various regions, including the Middle Atlas, south of the Grand Atlas, and the region of Taza . Casablanca served as a base to subdue the Chaouia tribes . The French colonial administration introduced modern public health measures and work discipline . Colonial settings, like Morocco, were used to experiment with welfare society norms before they were implemented in France . French urban planning in Morocco during the colonial period involved two approaches: \"techno-cosmopolitanism\" and \"middling modernism\" . \"Techno-cosmopolitanism\" aimed to integrate general planning principles with specific cultural and social contexts, operationalizing history, society, and culture . Modernization under French colonialism involved identifying and operationalizing Moroccan tradition to achieve health, productivity, and efficiency ."

                                "text": "Following France's defeat by Nazi Germany in June 1940, Morocco, as a French protectorate, fell under Axis dominion . Casablanca came under Vichy authority . Marshal Philippe Pétain, head of the Vichy regime, also led France's colonial possessions, including Morocco . In November 1942, Anglo-American forces landed in French North Africa as part of Operation Torch . The Allied landing occurred on November 8, 1942 . General Eisenhower was the Commander in Chief of Operation Torch . The operation aimed to capture Casablanca, Oran, Algiers, and Tunis . French Casablanca came under bombardment early in the morning of November 7 by American admirals . American troops advanced towards Casablanca on land along the Casablanca-Rabat highway against French artillery fire . Allied forces defeated the Vichy resistance in Casablanca after an intense bombardment from November 8-11 . French Casablanca surrendered on November 11 after experiencing heavy losses . After the victory against Axis defenders, the Americans allowed the French to temporarily hold power in Casablanca . The Vichy French were defeated in Morocco, ending Axis rule in the region ."

President Roosevelt and Churchill met with Resident General Noguès and Sultan Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef . President Franklin D. Roosevelt visited Moroccan King Muhammad V in a suburb of Casablanca and promised him independence . Roosevelt's promise generated a wave of Moroccan nationalism . The support of the United States and the United Kingdom for Moroccan independence angered French authorities . In 1945, a famine occurred in Morocco, for which the French did nothing, while the Americans offered food aid . Muhammad V praised the American government in Tangier, ignoring praise to the French government, in the presence of French officials . France exiled Muhammad V in 1952, causing the citizens of Morocco to associate their nationalism with Muhammad V’s exile . France restored Muhammad V to the throne after facing public disapproval and a revolution in Morocco . In 1955, Muhammad V met with the French Foreign Minister in Paris and declared the end of a “minor jihad” to gain independence ."

In November 1941, Moroccan Jews were to cease practicing prohibited professions or face imprisonment and fines, though exemptions were possible . Léon René Sultan lost his French citizenship and was disbarred due to Vichy laws; he continued to advocate against the protectorate authorities . Forced labor camps in Morocco housed Eastern European Jews and political prisoners, with approximately 7,000 prisoners, about one-third Jewish, building the Trans-Saharan Railway . Hélène Cazes Benatar established the Moroccan Refugee Aid Committee to assist refugees in Morocco during the Vichy period . President Roosevelt met with Resident General Noguès in Casablanca in January 1943 and expressed views on limiting the number of Jews in professions in North Africa ."

                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://edumag.uomustansiriyah.edu.iq/index.php/mjse/article/download/1055/798"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Treaty of Fez (معاهدة فاس), signed on March 30, 1912, between France and Morocco, marked a pivotal moment in Moroccan history, establishing the French Protectorate over the country . This event was the culmination of increasing European influence and internal strife within Morocco . Prior to the treaty, Morocco faced numerous challenges, including a weakened state, internal rebellions, and financial instability . Sultan Hassan I attempted reforms in the late 19th century, but faced resistance . The defeat in the Battle of Isly in 1844 further weakened Morocco and increased European influence . After Hassan I's death, Sultan Abd al-Aziz's reign (1894-1908) was characterized by financial instability and internal rebellions, including the Zerhouni rebellion in 1901 . Moulay Hafid began considering taking over from his brother Abd al-Aziz as early as 1907 and was proclaimed Sultan in Fez on August 15, 1907, under conditions of expelling Europeans ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://edumag.uomustansiriyah.edu.iq/index.php/mjse/article/download/1055/798",

                                ],
                                "text": "European powers, including France, Spain, Italy, and Great Britain, had been vying for control over Morocco . France signed various agreements with these powers between 1904 and 1911 to pave the way for its control . The Algeciras Conference in 1906 affirmed the sovereignty of Morocco while opening the door to greater European involvement . The Franco-Spanish Convention of 1904 aimed to balance French and Spanish interests in Morocco . However, the Agadir Crisis in 1911 heightened tensions and accelerated the process leading to the French protectorate . Germany sent a gunboat to Agadir amidst an uprising against Sultan Abdelhafid, prompting France to send troops to Fez . A definite treaty of diplomatic alliance between France and Morocco was concluded in February 1910 ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Context"

The treaty ceded the sovereignty of Morocco to France and is referred to as the 'Treaty of Protection' . It assigned the task of implementing administrative, financial, and judiciary reforms to the colonial power . The treaty also tasked the Protectorate with modernizing education and the army ."

                                "text": "Article 1 of the Treaty focused on implementing reforms while safeguarding the Sultan's status . Article 2 permitted the French government to occupy territories needed for the maintenance of order . Article 3 stated that the French government was to lend constant support to the Sultan and protect him against any danger . Article 4 focused on enabling the Moroccan army to be reorganized under French oversight . Article 5 stated that the French government was to represent the Sultan in all foreign affairs . Article 6 is cited as an example of international agency in practice, where one subject of international law acts on behalf of another ."

                                "text": "The French administration, initially under General Lyautey, aimed to establish French control while appearing to respect Moroccan traditions and institutions . Lyautey served as Resident General from 1912 to 1925 . He adopted a policy of respecting Islam and Moroccan customs . Lyautey believed it would be an error not to respect Islam in Morocco, as Islam was in the possession of the Moroccans . The French aimed for economic and moral penetration of Morocco through close association, administering the country through its own government organs and respecting its customs, as opposed to direct rule or annexation . Lyautey emphasized the importance of respecting Islam to ensure smoother administration and the pacification of Morocco . France aimed to restore order, unify the Empire, and re-establish the state in Morocco under the guise of police actions to manage the Makhzen ."

Colonial agriculture focused on land reform, technological equipment, and exclusive access to foreign markets, disrupting traditional agriculture . Land reform involved privatization of public domain and seizure of tribal lands ."

The introduction of French into the educational system shaped Moroccan identity . After Morocco gained independence in 1956, the government's language policy aimed to reconstruct Arab-Moroccan national identity by prioritizing standard Arabic in public education . However, French remained the language of the upper classes and is required for fluency in key sectors . The French language became the official language of the colonial administration in Morocco starting in 1912 ."

                                "text": "The Portuguese presence in North Africa spanned from 1415 to 1769 . Driven by military ambitions, the protection of trade routes, imperial expansion, and the ideals of the Reconquista and the Crusades, the Portuguese sought to establish a network of military and commercial bases along the Moroccan Atlantic coast . This expansion, beginning with the capture of Ceuta in 1415, extended south and east, relying on advanced navigation skills and the introduction of flanking fire defenses . The Portuguese expansion project dates back to the late 13th century with the Treaty of Soria in 1291 . The victory over the Marinids in the battle of Salado in 1340 gave fresh impetus to the Portuguese expansionist intents . The Portuguese King Afonso IV got the enactment of the Papal Bull Gaudemus et exultamus in May 30th 1341, acknowledging the Portuguese Crown the right to conquer the Kingdom of Fez . The Aviz dynasty resumed the expansionist project, prioritizing the Atlantic strategy over expansion to Granada ."
