Dom Afonso V's forces attacked and penetrated Asilah on August 24, 1471, taking the city by surprise . The conquest of Ceuta in 1415 marked the starting point of the implementation of this strategy and the benefit to the maritime cities involved in maritime trade with northern Europe . Ceuta was considered the key to the Strait, impacting commercial circulation to and from the Mediterranean and the safety of coastal communities . The capture of Asilah caused fear among the residents of Tangier, located 38 kilometers away, who abandoned the city, opening its doors to the Portuguese . By the end of 1471, the Portuguese controlled the main cities on the African shore of the Strait of Gibraltar . The capture of Asilah and Tanger marked the start of Portuguese rule in northern Morocco ."

The Portuguese enslaved 250 Jews from Asilah after the conquest . Isaac Abravanel organized a committee and raised funds to rescue 220 of these Jewish prisoners . The Portuguese in Asilah constructed a fortified belt adapted to recent military techniques for gunpowder combat . King Manuel I reduced Asilah's urban area for military sustainability, a technique called 'atalho' applied to other Portuguese conquests in the Maghreb .                                 "text": "In 1509, Master builder Diogo Boytac was called to Asilah to build a new donjon and establish a work plan for further construction . In 1510, Diogo Boytac was sent to Asilah to build new walls and the Menagem tower . Francisco Danzilho continued Boytac's work between 1511 and 1514 . The 1514 Livro das Medidas das fortalezas de Arzila, Alcácer, Ceuta e Tânger documents the works carried out at the northern strongholds . The Portuguese constructed a fortified belt adapted to recent military techniques for gunpowder combat . A housing program was implemented in Asilah to replace houses destroyed in the 1508 assault . References to 'old town' versus 'new town' suggest a new town grid scheme was established in Asilah by the Portuguese . The Portuguese urban fabric in Asilah included geometrically rectangular blocks divided by perpendicular and parallel streets to the main square . The Rua Direita, the traditional spine of Portuguese medieval cities, was present in Asilah, corresponding to either Tijara, Sidi Ali Ben Handouch, or Bab R’Mel streets . The Portuguese focused on street pavement and water supply in Asilah, including a public fountain . Structures known as couraças were built in Asilah, Tangier, and Ksar es-Seghir as early as 1502 to provide garrisons with easy access to water ."

            {
                "article_title": "The Portuguese Conquest of Ceuta: A Turning Point in Iberian and Moroccan History",
                "date": {
                    "hijry": {
                        "approx": true,
                        "end": 818,

                        "end": 1415,

                "event_name": "احتلال البرتغاليين لسبتة",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://brill.com/downloadpdf/display/book/9789004661219/B9789004661219_s035.pdf",
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/ar/Issue10/Pages/Ostour10-2019-Cherif.pdf",
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/ar/Issue10/Pages/art04.aspx",
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/en/Issue10/Pages/art04.aspx"
                                ],
                                "text": "Ceuta (سبتة), a city located on the North African coast at the Strait of Gibraltar, held significant strategic and commercial importance in the medieval Mediterranean . Its location made it a key point for trade between Morocco and the Iberian Peninsula, serving as Morocco's gateway to the outside world and a major transit point between Europe and Africa . The city was a central hub for Mediterranean trade and a crucial point of contact between Christian and Muslim powers . During the later Muslim period, Ceuta's strategic position and defenses were of great importance . The city enjoyed a period of autonomy, highlighting its significance in the Strait of Gibraltar region, which was contested by Christian (Castile, Aragon, Genoa, Portugal) and Islamic (Moroccan, Nasrid) powers ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Strategic Importance of Ceuta"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/216862323.pdf",
                                    "https://e-spacio.uned.es/bitstreams/f1a88b6c-93e5-46d5-ae5a-6aab05fe11f0/download",
                                    "https://ostour.dohainstitute.org/ar/Issue10/Pages/Ostour10-2019-Cherif.pdf",
                                    "https://repositorio-aberto.up.pt/bitstream/10216/154882/2/649405.pdf",
                                    "https://repositorium.uminho.pt/bitstream/1822/7288/1/Paper_Jorge%20CORREIA.pdf",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781315122915-4/challenge-sent-duke-holland-embassies-preparations-enterprise-ceuta-ordered-king-virginia-de-castro-almeida-bernard-miall",
                                    "https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781351022866-9/another-1415-portugal-military-landscape-time-agincourt-jo%C3%A3o-gouveia-monteiro-miguel-gomes-martins-tiago-vi%C3%BAla-de-faria"
                                ],
                                "text": "By the early 15th century, Portugal, under King John I of the House of Avis, sought to expand its territory and influence . The Portuguese aimed for economical and commercial benefits, Europe’s recognition, and religious Reconquest through their seizures and foundations in Northern Africa . The conquest of Ceuta was seen as a way to demonstrate Portugal's legitimacy as a world power and to secure its position among other Christian monarchs . The notion of reconquest, with Portuguese kings claiming rightful inheritance to North African territories, also played a role . The Portuguese preparations for the attack on Ceuta were shrouded in secrecy, causing concern among other Iberian powers and even within Portugal itself . To maintain secrecy, King Dom Joao devised a pretext for the military preparations by challenging the Duke of Holland, threatening war due to injuries and thefts suffered by Portuguese merchants in Holland . Fernao Fogaca was sent to inform the Duke of Holland about King Dom Joao's plans and the necessity of a pretext to avoid alarming the Moors . The King also assigned preparation and administrative tasks to his sons ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Portuguese Motivations and Preparations"

The Portuguese amphibious landing involved a large fleet of ships and a substantial army . The fleet, consisting of 242 ships, sailed from Lisbon on June 23, 1415, carrying 50,000 soldiers and seamen . The landing occurred at the Almina beach, exploiting a defensive lapse by the city's defenders . The population of Ceuta resisted the Portuguese invasion but were ultimately overwhelmed . Gomes Eanes de Zurara wrote a chronicle describing the walls and moats crossed during the Portuguese conquest of Ceuta ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Portuguese garrison, numbering around 3,000 men under D. Pedro de Meneses, faced challenges adapting to a different style of warfare centered on mobility and ambushes, unlike the heavy cavalry tactics they were accustomed to . Horses were essential for the Portuguese garrison in Ceuta for reconnaissance, raiding, and defense against the Marinid forces . The garrison faced sieges between 1418 and 1419 by Marinid forces and a Granadan fleet, which were eventually broken by the arrival of a Portuguese relief force . D. Pedro de Meneses established a reconnaissance network using watchtowers and sea patrols to monitor enemy movements . The garrison relied on supply ships from Portugal to maintain the city and prioritize experienced warriors to minimize casualties . The Portuguese utilized mounted units in skirmishes outside the city gates, feigning retreats to draw enemies into range of crossbow fire . During sieges, mounted units harassed enemy siege lines and sabotaged attacks . The local Moroccan armies generally had superior numbers of mounted units compared to the initial Portuguese garrison . The Portuguese acquired horses through raids on North African villages and purchases from foreign markets . The 'Casa de Ceuta' in Lisbon was created to supply the fortress, including horses and war materiel . Portuguese raids on North African villages targeted cattle, including horses . The Portuguese used almogavars (light footmen) for reconnaissance ahead of the main force during raids . The Portuguese garrison, after withstanding initial challenges, expanded its area of influence through raids and skirmishes . D. Duarte de Meneses, son of D. Pedro, adopted a more aggressive military policy, using tactics like feigned retreats . D. Pedro de Meneses died in Ceuta during the disastrous expedition to Tangiers in 1437 . Portuguese forces attempted to take the castle of Tetuan in 1435 but were repelled . The garrison used naval assets to support land forces, transporting footmen to coastal targets while cavalry moved overland ."

Ceuta's bastion fortifications were built between 1541 and 1549 . In 1541, the plans for the fortress of Ceuta proposed the construction of a wide, deep ditch, also used as a maritime channel, ensuring separation between the town and the mainland . The plans for Ceuta introduced the bastioned model and included an improved system of access from the exterior field and from the sea . Bastions, curtains and repairs on the bastioned land front in Ceuta were carried out by integrating the ancient walls into the new construction . A new system of access from the exterior field was established in Ceuta – a side entry protected against assault from land – leading to a reduction in the defensive perimeter and the demolition of an existing urban area ."

Englishmen initially hoped Tangier would become a prosperous trading center and a base against Muslim corsairs . The English crown established Tangier as a free port and crown colony . A proclamation was issued on November 16, 1662, declaring Tangier as a free port . The free port of Tangier was intended to be an international free-trade environment for all merchants, modeled after Livorno and Genoa . However, Tangier was not successful as a Mediterranean free port . The English occupation of Tangier was marked by mismanagement, domestic political tensions, and Moroccan resistance . The English abandoned and demolished Tangier in February 1684 . Tangier had to resist the Moors in the 17th century while Morocco was vigorous ."

Their involvement in politics began in 1195 when they aided the Almohads in the Battle of Alarcos . They captured Marrakech in 1269 . The Marinid rule is generally divided into three distinct eras: a period of establishment and consolidation (1215-1269), a golden era characterized by prosperity and strength (1269-1335), and a final era marked by decline and eventual downfall (1358-1465) . This final period witnessed the gradual erosion of Marinid authority and the ascendance of the Wattasids ."

                            {

                                ],
                                "text": "Several internal factors contributed to the weakening of the Marinid Kingdom and paved the way for the Wattasid takeover . These included constant fighting for the throne, particularly after the death of Sultan Abu Inan Faris, which created instability and weakened the central authority . Weak leadership in the wake of Abu Inan Faris's death further exacerbated the situation . The excessive power wielded by the viziers, especially during the era of Wizarat Tafwid (delegated power to the viziers), significantly undermined the Sultan's authority and allowed the viziers to usurp power . A dwindling spirit of jihad also contributed to the decline ."

                                "text": "The Wattasids held a significant position within the Marinid administration, ultimately enabling them to seize power . The appointment of Jews to key administrative positions, particularly the appointment of Harun ibn Batash as a vizier by Sultan Abd al-Haqq II (1420-1465), proved to be a controversial decision . This decision sparked a reformation movement led by the Wattasids, culminating in the toppling of Sultan Abd al-Haqq II and the end of Marinid rule in 1465 . The Marinid Kingdom was ultimately toppled by the Wattasids, who had previously served the kingdom as viziers ."

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/ephe_0000-0001_1995_num_11_1_8089"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Wattasids replaced the Marinids in 1465 . The period following the Wattasid takeover, from 1465 to 1580, is described as a \"Hundred Years War for Morocco\" . This era, encompassing the early modern Maghrib, was characterized by warfare and state building . The Wattassids ruled in Maghreb al-Aksa . However, the Wattassids, along with the 'Abd al-Wadids and the Hafsids, experienced a decline in their authority . The Wattassides and 'Abd al-Wadids disappeared from the political scene in 1554 . The conference series focuses on European sources of the history of the Maghreb from 1492 to 1578 . The fall of Constantinople in 1453 and the Reconquista of Granada (1482-1492) are mentioned as contextual events . The source also discusses the impact of European powers and the rise of Ottoman influence in the Maghreb . The Hafsids declined approximately twenty years later ."

                                "text": "The Portuguese expansion along the Atlantic coast began in the 15th century, driven by a complex interplay of economic, religious, and political factors . A primary motivation was the desire to find new trade routes to the East, bypassing the established routes controlled by the Arab and Ottoman Empires . This quest was fueled by the increasing European demand for spices and luxury goods . The Portuguese also sought access to African gold and slaves . Religious zeal, particularly the desire to spread Christianity and combat Muslim influence, provided further impetus for exploration and conquest ."

The colonization of Santiago in Cape Verde began in 1462, with Fogo colonized later . These islands served as crucial hubs for trade and navigation in the Atlantic ."

Gil Eanes crossed Cape Bojador in 1434, a feat that opened the way for further exploration southward . By 1460, the Portuguese had explored the western African coast as far as Sierra Leone . They established trading posts (feitorias) along the coast, exchanging European goods for African products such as gold, ivory, and slaves . Elmina, established in 1482, became a major trading post on the Gold Coast ."

                                "text": "The Portuguese expansion along the Atlantic coast had a lasting impact on both Portugal and the regions it touched . It transformed Portugal into a major maritime power, contributing to its wealth and influence . It also led to the development of new trade networks, the exchange of goods and ideas, and the creation of new societies in the Americas . However, it also resulted in the exploitation and enslavement of millions of Africans, leaving a lasting legacy of inequality and injustice ."

                                "text": "The Nasrid Kingdom of Granada, the last Muslim stronghold in Andalusia, maintained diplomatic relationships with various contemporary powers . Its history was intertwined with the Amazigh populations of North Africa . During the Nasrid emirate, Granada had a Zanata army corps . The Marinids, a Berber dynasty originating from Morocco, migrated and occupied part of the Nasrid territory during the Nasrid emirate . The Marinids, along with the Hafsids and Zayanids, were among the weaker powers in the Maghreb during the early 16th century, facing internal conflicts and external threats from Spain and Portugal ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Benimerines (Marinids) intervened in the Iberian Peninsula in support of the Nasrid kingdom of Granada during the 13th century . This intervention was a key factor in the 'Problema del Estrecho' (Strait Issue), a situation arising from the increasing power of the Christian kingdoms, the dominance of Christian fleets in the Mediterranean, and the intervention of North African Islamic empires . The 'Batalla del Estrecho' (Battle of the Strait) reached its peak in the first half of the 14th century . The Benimerin Sultan Abu-l-Hassán prepared an expedition to conquer the Iberian Peninsula . However, Christian states, particularly Castile and Portugal, supported by the fleets of Aragon and Genoa, defeated the Muslims, including the Benimerines, in the Battle of Salado in the first half of the 14th century . This victory ended the 'Problema del Estrecho' and established Christian hegemony in the Iberian Peninsula ."

Some argue that the Knight may have fought for Sultan Muḥammad V of Granada . The siege of Algeciras in question happened in late July 1369, directed by Sultan Muḥammad V . The Knight's military career included service in the Levant, eastern Baltic, and kingdoms around the straits of Gibraltar . The Knight fought in Algeciras and is linked to the emirate of Morocco (Belmarye, Banū Marīn) . King Alfonso XI of Castile took Algeciras from Granada in 1344 . In 1344, Alfonso's Iberian-Genoese coalition defeated an army sent by the Moroccan Sultan Abū’l-Ḥasan ‘Alī to relieve Algeciras . Sultan Muḥammad V was an ally of King Pedro I of Castile and sent troops to help him fight Enrique de Trastámara . After Pedro’s murder, Muḥammad V took territory along the border, including Algeciras . Muḥammad V allied with the Marinids and Zayanids . The Marinid emirate of Fez in Morocco and the Zayanid emirate of Tlemcen (in modern Algeria) were allies of Granada . The Knight may have fought for Muḥammad V from late March 1369, through the siege of Algeciras in late July 1369, and into the 1370s . The source suggests the Knight may have been involved in the campaigns to take Gibraltar and Ceuta for Granada in 1372 . The Knight’s potential service with the Zayanids involved pushing the Marinids out of Tlemcen ."

                                "text": "Lisan al-Din Ibn al-Khatib, a vizier of the Nasrid sultans of Granada, had a close relationship with the Merinid sultans of Fes (Morocco) . This relationship spanned approximately 25 years, from the beginning of Ibn al-Khatib's career in 1340 to his death in 1375 . Ibn al-Khatib served multiple Nasrid sultans in Granada and dealt with at least ten different Merinid sultans . Key Merinid sultans included Abū l-Ḥasan ʿAlī, Abū ʿInān Fāris, Abū Bakr al-Saʿīd, Abū Zayyān Muammad II, Abū l-Fāris ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz, Abū Zayyān Muammad III, and Abū l’ʿAbbās Amad . Ibn al-Khatib's writings, such as the 'Rayānat al-kuttāb', are important sources for understanding the period . He undertook diplomatic missions to Morocco and facilitated the passage of Merinid princes through Granada . The political intrigues and rivalries within both the Merinid and Nasrid courts played a significant role . Ibn al-Khatib's exile and death in Fez were linked to Granada and the Merinids ."

                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://bokundoli.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/T4-9.pdf",

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1975_num_20_1_1329"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Marinid dynasty, originating from the Zab region in Ifriqiya, established themselves in the central Maghrib plains . They were a Berber dynasty who rose to power after attacking an Almohad convoy around 1145 . By 1269, Abu Yusuf invested Marrakech and was proclaimed sultan, marking the beginning of their rule in the Maghrib until 1465 . The Marinids' rise coincided with the decline of the Almohad empire, which led to the emergence of three states: Ifriqiya, the extreme Maghreb (Marinids), and the central Maghreb, controlled by the Abd al-Wadid dynasty . The Abd al-Wadids, a Zenata tribe, established an independent dynasty in the central Maghreb, with Tlemcen as their capital . The Banu Abd al-Wad were part of the Zanata Berber tribe and shared nomadic origins with the Marinids . The Marinids, initially nomadic, expanded their power by incorporating Zanata from central Maghreb and Arab troops into their armies, supplementing them with mercenaries . The Marinids' expansionist ambitions brought them into direct conflict with the Abd al-Wadids of Tlemcen . The Abd al-Wadid dynasty's history involved a double relationship: with the Almohad caliphate in the 13th century and the Marinids from the 14th century onward ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Context"

                                "text": "A major conflict between the Marinids of Fez and Tlemcen began around 1295, initiating a period of Marinid aggression . Under Abu Said Othman ben Ya`qub, the Marinids besieged Tlemcen for eight years, from 1299 to 1307 . During this prolonged siege, the Marinid Sultan Abu Yacoub Youcef built the town of Mansourah near Tlemcen as a military camp to replace Tlemcen . The mosque of Mansourah was built around 1303 by Sultan Abu Yacoub . The siege impacted the city and its population, causing hardship . The poet Ibn Khamīs al-Tilimsānī fled Tlemcen in 1305 during the siege . He composed nostalgic poems called Tilimsāniyyāt while in exile . The siege was lifted in 1307 due to the assassination of the Marinid sultan ."

The Marinid rule installed in Tlemcen from 1337 favored the settlement of Hilalian Arabs north of Chlef, in contact with Ouarsenis ."

Tlemcen returned to Abd al-Wadid control in 1359 after a revolt, marked by Hammū II's accession ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Marinids (Bani Marin) were a Zenata Berber tribe originating from the central Maghreb, specifically the region between Tlemcen and Tahar . They were initially nomadic tribes from the Zab region, located on the border between modern Algeria and Tunisia . From the early 13th century onwards, they began to expand their influence in the Maghreb . Their initial expansion was largely driven by plunder, and unlike the Almoravids and Almohads, they lacked a strong unifying religious or political ideology ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Marinids emerged as major competitors to the Almohad state, gradually undermining their rule for over 58 years . The decline of the Almohad empire, particularly following the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa in 1212, and internal conflicts among Almohad claimants facilitated the Marinids' rise to power . Abu Bakr Yahya bin Abdul Haq al-Marini entered Fez in 642 AH/1248 CE, marking the beginning of Marinid rule in that city . The Marinids systematically conquered the Maghreb al-Aksa (modern Morocco) over several decades, capturing important cities such as Fes and Meknes . Prince Yaqoub bin Abdul Haq seized Marrakech, the Almohad capital, in 668 AH/1269 CE, effectively ending the Almohad state in the Maghreb . After the decline of the Almohad Empire, the Marinids emerged as one of three successor dynasties in 1258 ."

The Qarawiyyin Mosque's Dar al-Muwaqqit in Fes was added by the Marinids in 1286 during renovations of the mosque's minaret . Water clocks were commissioned by Marinid Sultan Abu Yusuf Ya'qub in the 13th century and designed by Muhammad ibn al-Habbak . Another water clock was constructed on the orders of Sultan Abu Said in 1317 and restored in 1346 . The Marinids also contributed to the architectural heritage of Tlemcen, Algeria, with rich polychromic expressions found in geometric and floral shapes decorating minarets, porches, interior courtyards, and patios of buildings ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Río Salado, fought in 1340, was a significant event in the context of the Reconquista in the Iberian Peninsula . The Marinid dynasty, a Muslim power controlling parts of North Africa and Iberian coastal ports, had become a major adversary of the Christian kingdoms in Iberia, particularly Castile . Alfonso XI of Castile, who reigned from 1312 to 1350, heavily relied on the Castilian navy in his military strategies, especially in the southern Iberian conflicts around the Strait of Gibraltar . Alfonso XI struggled for control of the Strait of Gibraltar, contending with both the Nasrid emirate of Granada and the Marinids . The Castilian navy played a crucial role in protecting shipping and coastal areas, gathering intelligence, supporting land forces, and engaging in direct naval confrontations ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/ARCO_BURES_2021_01_0119"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Marinids themselves originated as nomadic tribes in the Zab region, on the border between present-day Algeria and Tunisia . They were considered second-generation Zenata, following other groups like the Miknâsa and Banû Ifrân . Initially, they served the Zirid and Hammadid dynasties, guarding their borders . However, the Hilalian Arab expansion restricted their nomadic range . They offered limited support to the Almohad regime and later exploited the Almohads' decline after the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa in 1212 to expand their influence through pillage . For at least 25 years after their first victory over the Almohads in 1216-1217, the Marinids focused on plunder and tribute collection, lacking a distinct political or religious ideology ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background to the Battle"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://muse.jhu.edu/pub/162/article/588964/summary",
                                    "https://www.dialogosmediterranicos.com.br/RevistaDM/article/view/491"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Río Salado in 1340 saw Alfonso XI of Castile defeat the Marinids . This victory is presented as a turning point in the Reconquista . A speech attributed to King Afonso IV of Portugal, delivered around 1380, connected the Battle of Salado to earlier battles between Christians and Muslims, framing it as part of an ongoing narrative of Christian victories . This narrative began with the perceived loss of Spain and focused on the reconquest of those lands by Christian ancestors . The *Livro de Linhagens* and the *Crónica de 1344*, written by Pedro Afonso de Barcelos, compiled stories relating to this narrative, and these texts underwent multiple revisions throughout the 14th century . The Reconquista of the Iberian Peninsula became a collective memory that gave meaning to the Battle of Salado ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Alcácer Quibir, also known as the Battle of the Three Kings or the Battle of Wadi al-Makhazin (معركة وادي المخازن القصر الكبير), took place on August 4, 1578, in northern Morocco, near the town of Ksar el-Kebir . This battle was a pivotal event with far-reaching consequences for both Portugal and Morocco, significantly altering the geopolitical landscape of North Africa and Europe . The battle occurred in the context of the late 16th century, a period marked by the rise of the Ottoman Empire and religious conflicts ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [

                                ],
                                "text": "Several factors contributed to the outbreak of the battle. King Sebastian of Portugal, born in Lisbon on January 20, 1554, inherited the Portuguese crown at the young age of three in 1557 . His ten-year reign was largely focused on reviving territorial conquests in Africa . Sebastian, driven by religious fervor and a desire for military glory, sought to expand Portuguese influence in North Africa, contrasting with his grandfather's more cautious approach . He viewed the expedition as a new crusade ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p2",

Mulei Mohammed sought Portuguese assistance to regain his throne, providing King Sebastian with a pretext for intervention ."
                            }

                                ],

The Portuguese army consisted of approximately 9,000 men, fewer than the planned 12,000 due to recruitment difficulties . The army's battle formation was a modified square, adapted to the terrain and circumstances . On June 24, 1578, Sebastian's forces, numbering around 20,000, set sail from Lisbon to Morocco ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "The Saadi dynasty of Morocco, under Abd al-Malik, had a well-organized army influenced by Ottoman military tactics . The Ottoman Empire significantly influenced the military organization and tactics of the Saadi army . The Saadi army's formation mirrored Ottoman tactics, with infantry in the center and cavalry on the flanks . Abd al-Malik's army utilized significant artillery, including pieces cast under his personal supervision . The Saadi army included diverse troops: Andalusians, Gazulas, Azuagos, Sharquis, and renegades ."

King Sebastian's death was confirmed by various accounts, including those of his companions . The battle resulted in a tragic defeat for the Christians, with 6,000-8,000 dead and around 8,000 prisoners . Three monarchs died in the Battle of Alcácer Quibir: King Sebastian of Portugal, Abd al-Malik, and Mulei Mohammed ."

João de Castro (1550-1628) is identified as a key figure in establishing the myth of King Sebastião's return . D. João de Castro used a collection of old and new prophecies to support the belief in King Sebastião's return . This action served to discredit D. António's aspirations to the throne of Portugal ."

                                "text": "The Battle of Alcácer Quibir was a watershed moment in Portuguese and Moroccan history . The battle resulted in a decisive Portuguese defeat, the death of King Sebastian, and the subsequent annexation of Portugal by Spain . The battle also gave rise to the myth of Sebastianism, which has profoundly shaped Portuguese national identity and cultural imagination . The battle continues to be a subject of historical and artistic interest, reflecting its enduring significance in the collective memory of both Portugal and Morocco ."

                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/9641245.pdf",

                                    "https://www.redalyc.org/journal/5215/521554287002/521554287002.pdf",

                                    "https://www.sybil.es/sybil/article/download/1619/1627"
                                ],
                                "text": "In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, European powers engaged in intense competition for colonial territories in Africa . Spain, seeking to regain international prestige after its defeat in 1898 and the loss of Cuba, the Philippines, and Puerto Rico, aimed to participate in the colonization of Morocco . Spain's foreign policy prioritized the security of its national territory . However, Spain's ambitions were challenged by other European powers, particularly France, which sought to establish a dominant presence in the region . Great Britain also sought to prevent French dominance near the Strait of Gibraltar ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-77950-4_4",
                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1970_num_7_1_1061",
                                    "https://www.sybil.es/sybil/article/download/1619/1627"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Madrid Conference of 1880 addressed the question of Morocco's partition but deferred a decision . France pursued a policy of \"peaceful penetration\" after 1900, aiming to exert influence over the Sultan through technical, financial, and military assistance . The Anglo-French Declaration of April 8, 1904, recognized French pre-eminence in Morocco and British support for a Spanish presence in western Morocco . The Franco-Spanish Declaration of October 3, 1904, and the secret Franco-Spanish Convention of the same date, demarcated the Spanish sphere of influence in the Rif region of northern Morocco . Germany's opposition to these agreements led to the Algeciras Conference in 1906 ."

                                "text": "The Algeciras Conference aimed to resolve imperial rivalries over Morocco . The Act of Algeciras created a de facto Franco-Spanish protectorate under vague international control . The Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE) opposed colonial wars and called for Moroccan independence . In 1912, the Spanish sphere of influence became the Spanish Protectorate under a Franco-Spanish Convention of November 27, 1912 . This agreement consolidated French supremacy in Morocco . France controlled the central and southern parts of Morocco, while Spain controlled a northern zone and several Saharan enclaves . The Moroccan government ceded military, diplomatic, and financial affairs to France and Spain ."

                                ],
                                "text": "In the early 20th century, Morocco was subjected to increasing European influence, culminating in the Treaty of Fez on March 30, 1912, which established a Franco-Spanish protectorate . This treaty divided Morocco into zones of influence, with France controlling the majority of the territory and Spain administering the northern and southern regions . The Algeciras Conference of 1906 had already recognized the rights of both Spain and France to exert influence in Morocco . The establishment of the protectorate, however, did not occur without resistance. The Berber tribes, in particular, mounted a strong opposition, besieging French forces in Fez in April 1912 . The Rif War (1921-1926), led by Abd el-Krim al-Khattabi, further demonstrated the strength of Moroccan resistance to colonial rule ."
                            },

                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "Despite the imposition of the protectorate, a sense of Moroccan national identity began to coalesce. This was fueled by several factors, including the influence of European ideologies, the growth of an educated elite, and the desire to preserve Moroccan culture and traditions . The Berber Dahir of 1930, which aimed to regulate Berber customary law and remove Berber tribes from Muslim law, sparked widespread protests and is often seen as a key turning point in the development of Moroccan nationalism . The Comité d’Action Marocaine (CAM), created in 1934, emerged as the first overtly nationalist party, advocating for reforms and a stricter application of the Protectorate regime . The CAM, led by figures like Allal al-Fasi, Mohamed Bel Hassan El Ouazzani, and Ahmed Balafrej, sought to abolish direct administration practices . However, the French authorities dissolved the CAM, and internal divisions led to its fragmentation ."
                            }

The Istiqlal Party emerged as an umbrella group of Moroccans fighting for independence from France . It comprised members from different sections of Moroccan society, including the traditional middle class from northern cities like Fez, the grand bourgeoisie, and intellectuals . Key figures in the Istiqlal Party included Ahmed Balafrej and Allal al-Fassi . The party's formation was influenced by the Moroccan Action Committee ."

The Independence Manifesto, approved by the sultan, called for Moroccan independence and the establishment of a democratic regime under the Sultan's leadership, similar to Muslim countries in the east . The manifesto, signed by prominent nationalist leaders, demanded full freedom for Morocco under Sultan Muhammad Ben Yussuf (Muhamad V) . The Istiqlal Party aimed to establish a British-style monarchy in Morocco where the sovereign reigns but does not rule . The publication of the manifesto led to the arrest of several nationalist leaders, further galvanizing the independence movement ."

                                "text": "Sultan Muhammad Ibn Yusuf (later King Mohammed V) gradually emerged as a key figure in the national movement . Initially, the Sultan had signed a dahir forbidding Moroccans from forming unions, viewing them as a threat to the Makhzen's authority . However, after the war, the Sultan began to express support for the nationalist cause . A pivotal moment occurred in April 1947 when Muhammed Ibn Yusuf visited Tanger, demonstrating the unity of Morocco and demanding independence . In his speech of April 9, 1947, in Tanger, the Sultan expressed his regret for the backwardness of the country and encouraged his compatriots to learn modern techniques, expressing confidence in their political awakening and the reclaiming of their rights . The Sultan's Tanger speech in 1947 is considered a milestone, marking his explicit joining of the forces struggling for national development and freedom ."

                                "text": "The growing nationalist movement and the Sultan's increasing support for it prompted a harsh response from the French authorities . General Alphonse Juin was appointed as resident general, restricting the activity of the nationalists and enforcing their leaders to leave the country . The French governor rejected the Moroccan sultan's support for the independence of Morocco in 1951 . In 1953, the French deposed Sultan Mohammed V, exiling him to Corsica and later Madagascar . The French replaced him with Arafat . This act sparked widespread protests and resistance, further strengthening the nationalist movement and solidifying the Sultan's image as a symbol of Moroccan unity . The Istiqlal Party continued to operate, seeking international support and advocating for the territorial integrity of Morocco . The Istiqlal opened the Moroccan Informational Bureau in New York at the end of 1947 . The Istiqlal sent a memorandum to the U.N. at the end of 1947, arguing that the Moroccan nation was a coherent political system before the French arrival, making the protectorate illegal ."

Morocco gained independence on November 18, 1956, due to the combined efforts of the Monarchy and the Istiqlal . The Istiqlal became critical of the monarchy after independence, believing they deserved to be in power . After independence, the title of 'Sultan' was replaced by 'King' ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s5_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://asfar.org.uk/the-struggle-for-power-post-independence-1956-62/",

                                    "https://www.multiresearchjournal.com/admin/uploads/archives/archive-1668938522.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The years following independence were marked by political instability and power struggles . King Mohammed V nominated a consultative assembly to assist in governing the nation in 1956 . The Istiqlal party was invited to form a government two years after independence but faced numerous restrictions . Internal divisions within the Istiqlal between the left wing led by Mehdi Ben Barka and the right wing led by Allal-el Fessie weakened the party . The Istiqlal mainly appealed to the urban middle class, limiting its overall support base . The Istiqlal split in 1958 over the issue of American military bases in Morocco . In January 1959, Prime Minister Abdallah Ibrahim formed a new-left wing party called the national union popular forces (UNFP) . The USFP is the successor of the “Union Nationale des Forces Populaires” (UNFP) which was created in January 1959 following internal division in the Istiqlal Party ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s5_p2",

                                    "https://asfar.org.uk/the-struggle-for-power-post-independence-1956-62/"
                                ],
                                "text": "King Mohammed V established a national police force and Royal Armed Forces (FAR) in May 1956, shifting control of key state apparatuses away from political parties . Mohamed Laghzaoui, a key financial sponsor of the Istiqlal, sided with the monarchy and became the director of national security and the head of the police . Abedlekrim el Khatib and Mahjoubi Aherdane, leading figures of the ALM, established the Popular Movement party, further damaging the Istiqlal's support base . The Istiqlal banned the PDI newspaper and was implicated in the assassination of Abbes Messaadi, a leader of the ALM ."

The Istiqlal's use of violent and repressive tactics contributed to their loss of power . The postcolonial Moroccan state was established in 1955 with the aim of creating a weak multiparty system and a powerful monarchy ."

                                "text": "Despite the initial power struggles, the Istiqlal Party remained a significant force in Moroccan politics . In 1993, the Istiqlal party became part of the democratic bloc “Koutla” and was part of the new government of 1997 . In March 1998, the Istiqlal party participated in a coalition government, headed by Abd al-Rahman Yussufi (USFP), marking the first time since 1960 that the monarchy entrusted authority to opposition parties in forming a government . In the 2007 elections, the Istiqlal Party took first place with 10.7% of votes and 15.9% of seats . In the 2011 elections, Istiqlal won 61 seats and became the second largest party . In 2021 the party won 81 seats in the parliamentary elections and is in a government coalition with the RNI and PAM . The USFP is the successor of the “Union Nationale des Forces Populaires” (UNFP) which was created in January 1959 following internal division in the Istiqlal Party ."

                "event_name": "حرب الريف ثورة عبد الكريم الخطابي (المغرب)",
                "sections": [
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://joergtiedjen.com/texte/Abdelkrim.pdf",
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/DEC_BOUCH_2013_01_0451",
                                    "https://www.iemed.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Transmediterranean-Political-Socialisation-The-Hirak-Movement-the-Moroccan-Diaspora-and-Europe-as-a-Political-Imaginary.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Rif War (1921-1926), also known as the Revolution of Abd el-Krim al-Khattabi, was a conflict between the Rif people of Morocco and the colonial powers of Spain and France . The Entente Cordiale of 1904 granted France freedom to act in Morocco, with the Rif region reserved for Spain . Morocco's history with Spain included memories of Al-Andalus and Spanish occupation after the Reconquista, with cities like Ceuta and Melilla serving as key locations . The Treaty of Protectorate, signed on March 30, 1912, with Sultan Moulay Hafid, formalized the division of Morocco, granting France the 'Maroc utile' and Spain control over the mountainous Rif region bordering the Mediterranean Sea . The Rif region was targeted for its mineral resources by industrialists in the late 19th century . Spain had maintained a network of informants and agents in northern Morocco since the 17th century ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Colonial Context"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://joergtiedjen.com/texte/Abdelkrim.pdf",
                                    "https://dehesa.unex.es/bitstream/10662/22878/1/shhc20213993120.pdf",
                                    "https://dehesa.unex.es/handle/10662/22878"
                                ],
                                "text": "Mohammed ben Abdelkrim el Khattabi emerged as a key leader in the Rif . Initially, Abdelkrim supported Spanish involvement in the Rif, believing it could lead to economic development and modernization . He even contributed to spreading the Spanish position through chronicles written in Arabic for *El Telegrama del Rif*, a Spanish newspaper founded in Melilla in 1902, aimed at promoting Spanish colonial action and the work of the Spanish military in Morocco . Abdelkrim's family had ties to the 'Partido español' and benefited from privileges as collaborators with the Spanish colonial enterprise . He criticized French colonial policies for exploiting the Moroccan economy . However, after World War I, Abdelkrim began to advocate for Rif independence and aligned with the Central Powers, leading to his arrest by the Spanish for treason ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Abd el-Krim: From Collaboration to Revolution"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://joergtiedjen.com/texte/Abdelkrim.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Rif War began with a Spanish offensive in 1920 intended to subdue the Rif-Kabylen . In July 1921, Abdelkrim's forces decisively defeated a Spanish army at Anoual, inflicting approximately 20,000 Spanish casualties . The Spanish General Sylvestre was pushed by King Alfons XIII to militarily conquer the area, but he underestimated the Rif . The defeat at Anoual marked a turning point in the Rif War . The Rif-Kabylen successfully resisted Spanish and later French forces for over five years and established the Rif Republic . The Rif Republic represented a challenge to colonialism and aspirations for liberation ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://joergtiedjen.com/texte/Abdelkrim.pdf",
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/ccec/6650"
                                ],
                                "text": "Following Anoual, Abdelkrim called for Jihad and gained support, eventually being recognized as Emir by the Rif tribes . In 1923, Abdelkrim proclaimed the Rif Republic, drafting a constitution and establishing a parliament and civil administration . The Rif Republic sought international recognition but was rejected by European powers . In September 1922, the Riff Committee of London sent two documents to the Council of the League of Nations, signed by Abdel Krim as \"president and commander in chief of the Republic of the Rif\" . Abdel Krim claimed his commitment to protect the rights of foreigners and govern in the interest of peace and international commerce . He also denounced the violence perpetrated by the Spanish, including the use of chemical weapons and destruction of sacred Islamic sites . Abdel Krim expressed willingness to negotiate an agreement with Madrid that would preserve the interests of the Spanish Monarchy in Morocco and the right to the existence of the Republic of the Rif ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Disaster of Anoual and the Rise of the Rif Republic"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/ccec/6650"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Spanish government, particularly after Primo de Rivera's coup, meticulously controlled the public representation of the military campaign in Morocco . In October 1924, the Spanish ambassador in London, Alfonso Merry del Val y Zulueta, sought to respond to press campaigns sympathetic to the Rif insurgents by writing under a pseudonym in *The Times* . The Spanish government used the Spanish Red Cross to prevent the International Committee of the Red Cross from sending a mission to Morocco ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://joergtiedjen.com/texte/Abdelkrim.pdf",
                                    "https://www.iemed.org/publication/transmediterranean-political-socialisation-the-hirak-movement-the-moroccan-diaspora-and-europe-as-a-political-imaginary/",

                                ],
                                "text": "Spain requested German assistance in developing poison gas after the defeat at Anoual, specifically for Yellow Cross gas . Despite restrictions from the Treaty of Versailles, Germany secretly continued developing chemical weapons . From 1922, Spanish aircraft dropped Yellow Cross bombs on the Rif, leading to immediate deaths and outbreaks of Typhus-like epidemics . The Spanish army used approximately 500 tons of mustard gas in the Rif region during the Rif War . The Rif War is considered the first aero chemical war in history, with poison gas missions carried out against civilian populations ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Spanish Brutality and International Involvement"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {

                                ],
                                "text": "France threatened Spain with the loss of its protectorate if it did not fully occupy its territory . France cut off the Rif's food supply in 1924, leading Abdelkrim to attack the French protectorate in 1925 . In 1925, the Rif forces advanced towards Fès and Taza, threatening French control of Morocco . Spain and France mobilized 800,000 soldiers against the Rif, including Moroccan auxiliary troops . In 1925, France allegedly used chemical weapons in the region of Fès to suppress an armed rebellion ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s4_p1",

In 1926, the Rif resistance collapsed due to a joint Spanish-French offensive, and Abdelkrim surrendered to France on May 27, 1926 ."

                                "text": "Abdelkrim was exiled to Réunion, and later sought asylum in Cairo . After escaping, Abd el Krim launched an appeal from Cairo for armed struggle against France . Abdelkrim died in Cairo on February 6, 1963, at the age of 81, and is revered in Morocco as a revolutionary and freedom fighter . Abdelkrim al-Khattabi (1882–1963) is mentioned as a revolutionary reference from Arab history, inspiring Mounir Shafiq's intellectual and political development ."
                            }

                                ],
                                "text": "After Moroccan independence in 1956, Abdelkrim Al-Khatabi questioned the newly appointed government's legitimacy . In 1957, an uprising in the Rif was brutally suppressed by King Mohamed V, led by his son Crown Prince Hassan . In 1958, the Northern Rif revolted and was brutally crushed by the Royal Armed Forces . In 1958 and 1959, General Mohammed Oufkir was known as 'the butcher of the Rif' . The Rif region acquired the status of a militarized zone after the 1958-59 revolt . In 1984, another uprising occurred after social protests, leading Hassan II to deploy tanks and insult demonstrators . King Hassan II described the Rif as \"waste\" and \"awbach\" leading to years of repression and economic marginalization ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Aftermath and Continued Resistance"
                    },

                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s7_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/anneemaghreb/10170",
                                    "https://revistas.uam.es/reim/article/view/reim2023_34_07",

                                    "https://www.iemed.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Transmediterranean-Political-Socialisation-The-Hirak-Movement-the-Moroccan-Diaspora-and-Europe-as-a-Political-Imaginary.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Rif War and the figure of Abdelkrim continue to resonate in the Rif region . The flag of the Republic of the Rif reappeared during the Arab Spring in Morocco . The Hirak movement, a protest movement that emerged in the Rif region of Morocco in 2016, connects to the Rif War of the 1920s led by Abdelkrim al-Khattabi . The Hirak movement uses Abdelkrim's portrait and the flag of the Rif Republic as symbols in its protests . The Hirak movement calls for greater economic and social investment in the Rif region, the freeing of political prisoners, and the inclusion of collective memory of the Rif in Moroccan history . The cancer rate in the Rif is believed to be a result of remnants of mustard gas deployed by the Spanish army during the Rif War (1921-1926) ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s7_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://amyaz.fr/uploads/66e0525b421ed.pdf",
                                    "https://www.iemed.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Transmediterranean-Political-Socialisation-The-Hirak-Movement-the-Moroccan-Diaspora-and-Europe-as-a-Political-Imaginary.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Hirak movement emerged in 2016 after the death of Mohsen Fikri, a fishmonger, in Al Hoceima . The Hirak was triggered by the death of Mohcin Fikri, a fish trader, in Alhuceima in November 2016 . The Hirak movement calls for greater economic and social investment in the Rif region by the Moroccan government . The Hirak insists on including the collective memory of the Rif region in Moroccan history . Hirak activists were sentenced to prison terms up to 20 years in summer 2018, a verdict that was confirmed in spring 2019 . The Hirak movement has mobilized the Moroccan diaspora in Europe, particularly those of Rifi origin . Support committees for the Hirak have been established in cities across Europe, including Brussels, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain, and Germany ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s7_p2",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://www.iemed.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Transmediterranean-Political-Socialisation-The-Hirak-Movement-the-Moroccan-Diaspora-and-Europe-as-a-Political-Imaginary.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Hirak movement is divided between a faction focused on socioeconomic demands and another advocating for independence from Morocco . Some Hirak activists see Europe as a symbol of dignity, equality, and social justice, contrasting it with the Moroccan regime . Kati Piri, a member of the European Parliament, has supported the Hirak's cause and addressed the human rights situation in the Rif . Nasser Zafzafi was nominated for the Sakharov Prize of the European Parliament and achieved second place . A parliamentary group called the Friends of the Rif has been formed to support the Hirak's cause . The Rif region has the highest rate of migration to Europe from Morocco ."
                            }

                        "subtitle": "The Rif War in Collective Memory and Modern Protest"

                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s8_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/VIN_158_0069"
                                ],
                                "text": "In 2021, Archives du Maroc requested the material restitution of the 'Abdelkrim Papers,' consisting of hundreds of documents written in Arabic by the leaders of the anticolonial resistance during the Rif War (1921-1926), seized by the French army when Mohamed ben Abdelkrim Al-Khattabi surrendered . The restitution request is part of a larger movement seeking the return of African \"cultural goods\" and \"colonial archives\" held in France ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s8_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/anneemaghreb/10170",
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/conflits/18827"
                                ],
                                "text": "Moroccan civil society organizations have sought recognition and reparations from Spain for the victims of chemical weapons used in the Rif War, citing the long-term health consequences like cancer in the Rif region . The Instance d’équité et de réconciliation (IER) established by Mohamed VI in 2004 addressed crimes committed in the Rif region . However, local actors criticized the IER for not fully addressing the truth about human rights violations in the Rif, particularly during the 1958-1959 events . Some argued that the IER's reparations process favored victims of the \"Years of Lead\" and neglected victims of earlier events, particularly the events of 1958-1959 ."

                                "text": "Morocco's history is marked by a struggle for territorial control and development, a theme that has shaped its policies for over a century . Even in the pre-colonial era, the Makhzen, or central government, faced challenges in exerting direct control over its territory, often relying on intermediaries such as tribal leaders and religious brotherhoods . Traditional organizations played a role in local development and land management . Robert Montagne described the tribe's political structure as progressing from a republican system to autocratic rule, followed by the intervention of the Makhzen and, ultimately, the dominance of 'Siba' (dissidence) ."

                                ],
                                "text": "European powers undermined Moroccan independence through debt and trade in the late 19th century . The French Protectorate, established in 1912 and lasting until 1956, significantly impacted Moroccan political and social structures . The colonial administration divided Morocco into a \"useful Morocco\" (plains and coastal regions) and a \"Berber Morocco\" (mountainous and Saharan regions) based on ethnicity and economic potential . The Berber Dahir of May 16, 1930, served as a catalyst for the Moroccan nationalist movement and the formation of political parties by threatening Islamic Law . This decree was a key element in the colonial policy of separating Berber populations from Arab populations and subjecting them to customary law . The Berber Dahir triggered a wave of opposition and contributed to the emergence of the Moroccan Nationalist Movement ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://www.cairn.info/load_pdf.php?ID_ARTICLE=MACHR1_164_0009&download=1&from-feuilleteur=1",

                                ],
                                "text": "Urban resistance to the colonial occupation was quickly suppressed, highlighting the cities' structural weaknesses inherited from the pre-colonial period . The الكتلة الوطنية (National Action Bloc) was formed in 1934 as one of the first Moroccan political parties . In 1937, French authorities arrested علال الفاسي, عمر عبد الجليل, and أحمد مكوار in October 25, 1937, and الوزاني five days later, suppressing the initial party formation . The الأحزاب الوطنية (Nationalist Parties) advocated for reforms, especially in political and economic sectors, during the initial phase of the Protectorate . Following the 1942 Anfa Conference, the حزب الاستقلال (Independence Party) was formed, and بلحسن الوزاني established the حزب الشورى والاستقلال (Consultation and Independence Party) . In July 1943, the Moroccan Communist Party was المغربة (Moroccanized) under the leadership of علي يعتة (Ali Yata) . The الأحزاب الوطنية (Nationalist Parties) advocated for independence and support for Sultan Mohammed V . The colonial policy led to the marginalization of the \"Berber Morocco\" and its isolation from the modernization process in the plains . France and Spain allied to crush the uprising of Mohamed ben Abdelkrim al-Khattabi in 1925 ."

                                ],
                                "text": "After independence in 1956, the Moroccan state faced the challenge of integrating a territory marked by regional disparities and power struggles . The army of liberation which contributed to the independence was repressed in 1958 which resulted in a fragile newly independent state . The state saw the countryside as places of weakness whereas urban areas were previously decisive for independence . The colonial legacy included a million hectares of land in the best regions of the country, along with modern farms and a diversified industry . The المخطط الخماسي (Five-Year Plan) of 1959-1960 was established by the الحركة الوطنية (National Movement) government led by عبد الله إبراهيم (Abdallah Ibrahim) . The government of Abdullah Ibrahim, during its time, forced the Palace to share power with the parties of the national movement . The برنامج الانعاش الوطني (National Recovery Program) was launched to combat unemployment under the supervision of the وزارة الداخلية (Ministry of Interior) . The المخطط الثلاثي (Three-Year Plan) between 1965 and 1968 focused on agriculture and tourism, aiming to reduce state intervention . During the 1960's until the late 1970's, Morocco entered a state of exception and political activism was banned . There were revolts in the High Atlas and Rif regions in 1958 as a result of the fragile state and the repression ."

                                "text": "Informal settlements remain prevalent in Morocco, often populated by those excluded by increased privatization . The 'Arab Spring' revealed a demand for the 'right to the city' . Lamia Zaki's chapter examines urban resistance movements in Moroccan slums from the 1990s to the Arab Spring . The chapter analyzes the dynamic relationship between public action and popular protest in Moroccan slums . The study focuses on the impact of national and international contexts on mobilizations and the ability of slum dwellers to influence public action . The research examines the impact of the Arab Spring on informal settlements, assessing transformations in the 'Villes sans bidonvilles' (Cities Without Slums) program in Casablanca . The 'Villes sans bidonvilles' (PVSB) program was initiated in 2005 to eliminate slums in urban areas . The PVSB program aimed to address 324,000 households (1.6 million inhabitants) in over 1,000 neighborhoods across 85 cities, including nearly a third in Casablanca . The article mentions the Mouvement du 20 février, the Moroccan version of the Arab Spring, and its impact . The study discusses the evolution of policies towards Moroccan slums, oscillating between prohibition, laissez-faire, promises of relocation, and threats of expulsion . The period following the Arab Spring saw increased difficulties for authorities to contain illegal construction and installations . The study highlights the creation of a national coordination of bidonvilles at the end of 2010 following the imprisonment of six residents of a bidonville in Mohammedia . The study mentions attempts by residents of bidonvilles to interfere in the attribution of titles and relocation ."

                                    "http://polcomp.free.fr/textes/seance3_mouniabennani.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "A study focusing on the politicization of actors in urban neighborhoods in Morocco, particularly in Casablanca, from 1998-2006, examined the relationship to politics through associative engagement . The research involved interviews and observations of three associations in Casablanca and a semi-urban area near the city, examining six experiences associatives initially . The study investigates how individuals with diverse backgrounds and experiences, including those with prior political activism and those new to political engagement, become involved in local associations . The associations studied operated in different neighborhoods: HH., a dense area of small collective housing built in the 1950s, and DS., a densely populated, older, and more commercial area . DJ association was founded in 1994 with the initial objective of raising the cultural level of the neighborhood HH after the elections of 1993 . Association M. for social development was created in 1998 around K., a deputy from the PJD (Parti de la justice et du développement) . AB association was also founded in 1998 around A., a former Marxist political prisoner, who became a local councilor . The study explores the actors' political competencies, distinguishing between technical/cognitive, social/status-related, and practical/pragmatic competence . The research examines the actors' feelings of injustice at local, national, and transnational levels, including issues like unemployment, poverty, corruption, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict . The study analyzes the boundaries that actors draw between \"us\" and \"them\" at various levels (local, national, transnational), including social cleavages, ideological divides, and perceptions of the political class . The research examines the impact of these factors on their participation in elections, noting different patterns of electoral behavior depending on the actors' political identities and perceptions . The study explores the actors' involvement in demonstrations and sit-ins related to national and international issues, highlighting the connections between local engagement and broader political movements . The research analyzes the role of neighborhood associations, noting their potential as spaces for social action, network expansion, and the emergence of alternative forms of political participation . The study highlights the fluidity of political engagement and the connections between local actions and the broader political landscape . The Dahir of 1958 regulates the right of associations, it was slightly modified in 2002 ."

                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/asinag/998"
                                ],
                                "text": "The history of Morocco, or ancient Mauretania, is marked by early resistance campaigns against foreign powers. The kingdom of Mauretania remained neutral during the conflict between Rome and Carthage . The war led by Jugurtha was a turning point in the region's history ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Pre-Roman Resistance"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/asinag/998"
                                ],
                                "text": "In the 1st century AD, Mauretania was occupied by Rome following the death of King Ptolemy and the subsequent revolt led by Aedemon . Despite the suppression of the Aedemon revolt, Roman campaigns and treaties failed to completely quell ongoing resistance . The revolt of the Mauri against Ascalis occurred towards the end of Bocchus' reign . Between 81 and 80 BC, Pompeius led a campaign that resulted in the destruction of cities like Zili, Sidi Abdel Salam del Behar, Thamusida, and Lixus . After Bocchus' death, Octavius intervened directly in Mauretania due to a succession crisis between 33 and 25 BC ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/asinag/998"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Roman resistance led to the establishment of settlements like Zili, Banasa, and Baba as footholds for control . The revolt of Aedemon occurred after the assassination of King Ptolemy and lasted for two years . Volubilis played a significant role in supporting the Romans during the period after 40 AD . Volubilis entered into an alliance with Rome, helping the Roman army in exchange for protection . This alliance occurred during the interregnum from 33 to 25 BC . The inhabitants of Volubilis sided with the Romans during the Aedemon war . The war of Aedemon began during the reign of Caligula and continued during the reign of Claudius, ending with a Roman victory in 42 AD . Some scholars believe the municipality of Volubilis was created during the Aedemon revolt . After the Aedemon revolt, Sextius Caecilianus was appointed to an administrative role in 75 AD . Suetonius Paulinus led the pursuit of the Mauri to the foothills of the Atlas Mountains . Hosidius Geta confronted the resistance of Salabus, which ended in a truce . In 42 AD, Emperor Claudius divided Mauretania into Mauretania Caesariensis and Mauretania Tingitana . The appointment of M. Fadius Celer Maximus as governor (Prolegatus) indicates that unrest continued in Mauretania Tingitana ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Roman Occupation and the Aedemon Revolt"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/asinag/823"
                                ],
                                "text": "Morocco's geographic location has resulted in a diverse culture influenced by various civilizations, including Amazigh . Linguistic and cultural diversity has been a fundamental characteristic and asset of Morocco throughout its history . The Amazigh language is considered the oldest language in Morocco and held a significant role in the past, including during the Almohad dynasty ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Linguistic and Cultural Resistance"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/asinag/823"
                                ],
                                "text": "The French protectorate (1912-1956) brought about significant socio-cultural and linguistic changes in Morocco . The French and Spanish implemented language policies aimed at promoting their respective languages during the colonial period . The French sought to establish French as the preferred foreign language in liberated colonies and as part of the colonies' identity . The French created a division between 'advanced' and 'underdeveloped' languages, favoring European languages over languages from the 'Third World' . The French colonial administration emphasized the importance of education in solidifying French linguistic policy . The French established different types of schools, including those for the general public and those for the elite, with French receiving a significant portion of instruction time . In 1912, the French established the 'École supérieure de langue arabe et dialectes berbères', which later became the 'Institut des Hautes Études Marocaines' in 1921, to train translators and administrators . Throughout the Protectorate, the French language was used in various official documents and reports, becoming the official language of the colonial authorities . The French protectorate authorities damaged the status of Classical Arabic due to their support and promotion of the French language . The French established French-Amazigh schools in the Middle Atlas region to appeal to the Amazigh population, with a focus on teaching practical agriculture, basic arithmetic, health, French, and written Amazigh using the Latin alphabet . The 'Collège d'Azrou' (secondary school) was established in 1930 by the French, aiming to integrate French influence in the Amazigh mountains . Despite efforts, the Collège d'Azrou largely directed Amazigh students towards French education and did not rely on the Amazigh language, thus failing to achieve its goals . The Spanish Protectorate did not develop as deep a linguistic policy as the French, but the prolonged occupation and cultural measures led to the spread of Spanish in the northern regions . After independence, the question of language arose, with some advocating for the French language, others opposing it, and some trying to reconcile both positions . The introduction of colonial education in Morocco resulted in a cultural duality, dividing the intellectual elite into those educated in the traditional system and those educated in the modern system . After independence, the French language continued to hold a prominent position in Morocco, being taught from primary school to university and used as the language of instruction in several faculties . The Moroccan constitution of 2011 recognized the Amazigh language alongside Arabic ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Colonial Resistance (Later Periods)"
                    }
                ]
            },

                                ],
                                "text": "The operations of the Moroccan Army of Liberation (جيش التحرير المغربي) are rooted in the complex history of Morocco's struggle for independence and the broader context of anti-colonial movements in North Africa . The Moroccan Army of Liberation was created to achieve independence and restore Sultan Muhammad bin Yusuf to the throne after his exile . The official establishment of the Moroccan Liberation Army was in Madrid in 1955 . Training bases were located in the northern region, and the army maintained close ties to the Istiqlal Party ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
