                                "text": "The Algerian War of Liberation (1954-1962) also provides a crucial backdrop . The Algerian Revolution was triggered by young activists within the التيار الثوري of the الحركة الوطنية الجزائرية after the المنظمة الخاصة (L’os) was dismantled by French police in March 1954 . The decision for armed struggle followed the internal crisis within the الحركة الوطنية (حزب الشعب الجزائري - حركة انتصار الحريات الديمقراطية PPA-MTLD) during its second congress in April 1953 . The Moroccan Liberation Army coordinated with other liberation armies in Algeria and Tunisia ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Origins"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/NAQD_HS5_0043?tab=texte-integral",
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/NAQD_HS5_0091"
                                ],
                                "text": "Internal divisions and differing visions for the future of the Maghreb influenced the Moroccan Army of Liberation . Abd al-Krim al-Khattabi, a prominent figure in Moroccan history, urged continued resistance in the Rif region even after the Franco-Moroccan declaration of March 2, 1956, which recognized Morocco's independence . He warned guerrilla fighters not to trust promises and to continue armed struggle as long as any French presence remained in Morocco . This contrasted with Sultan Muhammad V's call for a ceasefire to allow independence negotiations to conclude . This created a conflict in authority within the Moroccan Army of Liberation ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/NAQD_HS5_0091"
                                ],
                                "text": "Muhammad ibn Abd al-Karim al-Khattabi envisioned a unified \"Army of Liberation of the Arab Maghreb\" . He supported the complete independence of the Arab Maghreb and the creation of a single state in the Greater Maghreb . He feared that the independence of Tunisia and Morocco would come at the political cost of solidifying French control over Algeria . The Moroccan Liberation Army had two command structures: one based in Tetouan focusing on Moroccan independence and coordinating with other liberation armies in Algeria and Tunisia, and the other in Cairo, led by al-Khattabi, considering itself the \"Army of Liberation of the Arab Maghreb\" ."

Allal al-Fassi, leader of the Istiqlal Party, was critical of the negotiations for independence, deeming it incomplete and demanding the restoration of all Moroccan territories ."

The Ifni-Sahara War (1957-1958) began with attacks by Moroccan independentist forces in Sidi Ifni on November 23, 1957 . The Spanish forces suffered initial casualties . The Ejército de Liberación (EL), a Moroccan Army of Liberation, played a significant role in the events of 1956-1958 . The EL initially infiltrated Ifni and Sahara with the apparent tacit consent of the Spanish administration . Later, the Spanish authorities collaborated with the French in \"Operation Ecouvillon/Teide\" (February 1958) to expel the EL . The EL launched an attack on Ifni on November 23, 1957 . Spain lost 48 men in the combat of Edchera on January 13, 1958 . The region of Tarfaya was ceded to Morocco with the treaty of Cintra on April 10, 1958 ."

The United States supported French political projects in Morocco to prevent German presence on the Atlantic coast during the Conference of Algeciras in April 1906 . American forces landed in Morocco in 1942 as part of the North African landings during World War II . Agreements between Darlan and Clark in November 1942 led to the French army's unconditional surrender in Morocco, giving General Eisenhower control . The US supported France in Morocco due to Cold War strategic considerations, despite initial concerns about regional security ."

                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://gees.org/contents/uploads/docs/05042011065738_Analisis-08580.pdf",
                                    "https://dehesa.unex.es/bitstream/10662/13695/1/0213-375X_32_227.pdf",

                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/conflits/23540",
                                    "https://planetadelibrosec0.cdnstatics.com/libros_contenido_extra/38/37844_ABRAZO_MORTAL.pdf",
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/STRAT_093_0491"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Battle of Annual, a major military defeat for Spain in Morocco, took place in July 1921 in the Rif region of northern Morocco . This battle was a significant event in the Rif War (1921-1927), a conflict between the Spanish army and the Rif rebels led by Abd el-Krim . Spain's presence in Morocco was rooted in a desire to reclaim national honor after losing its American colonies in 1898 and to reintegrate into international alliances . European powers feared a Spanish agreement with another nation would threaten French sea routes and British control of Gibraltar . The Entente Cordiale of 1904 between Britain and France allocated a sphere of influence to Spain in northern Morocco . The Conference of Algeciras in 1906 stipulated that Morocco should be open to international trade and guaranteed the Sultan's sovereignty, tasking France and Spain with maintaining order in their spheres . The Treaty of Fez in 1912 formally established the Spanish Protectorate in Morocco ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "http://gees.org/contents/uploads/docs/05042011065738_Analisis-08580.pdf",
                                    "http://www.analecta.hu/index.php/mediterran_tanulmanyok/article/view/34489",
                                    "https://dehesa.unex.es/bitstream/10662/22877/1/hn_2022_6473.pdf",
                                    "https://planetadelibrosec0.cdnstatics.com/libros_contenido_extra/38/37844_ABRAZO_MORTAL.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "However, Spain's control was challenged by the Rif tribes, who sought independence . The Spanish zone encompassed approximately 22,000 square kilometers, including the Rif mountains, presenting significant geographical and climatic challenges for military operations . Armed resistance to Spanish penetration began in the late 19th century, including the Guerra de Margallo (1893-1894) . By 1919, the Spanish army in Morocco was suffering from technical insufficiencies and a diffuse command structure ."
                            }

By May 1921, the Spanish penetration had reached 130 kilometers to Buy Meyan and Annual . Silvestre's forces were spread across 140 isolated positions, making them vulnerable to attack . The location of the Spanish outposts was based more on political considerations than on military strategy . The Spanish troops were largely untrained conscripts, poorly equipped, and with low morale ."

                                ],
                                "text": "On July 22, 1921, approximately 5,000 Spanish soldiers in Annual were attacked by 18,000 Rif rebels . General Silvestre decided to evacuate Annual due to lack of water and the arrival of three columns of Rif rebels . The retreat from Annual turned into a disorganized rout, with many soldiers and officers abandoning their posts . Approximately 2,500 Spanish soldiers died in four hours during the retreat from Annual, in addition to another 1,500 from other positions . Approximately 492 Spanish soldiers were taken prisoner at Annual . The forces retreating from Annual fell back to Dar Drius and later to Monte Arruit, where they were besieged . General Navarro surrendered Monte Arruit on August 9, 1921, and almost all of the 3,000 soldiers were massacred by Abd el-Krim's forces . In total, approximately 10,000 Spanish soldiers died in the Disaster of Annual ."

                                ],
                                "text": "Several factors contributed to the Spanish defeat at Annual. The Spanish army suffered from technical insufficiencies, a diffuse command structure, and a lack of adequate training . The Reglamento Táctico de Infantería de 1914, based on Prussian military thought, was inadequate for irregular warfare against Abd el-Krim's forces . The overextension of General Silvestre's troops and the lack of a suitable military doctrine for counter-insurgency warfare also played a role . The location of the Spanish outposts was based more on political considerations than on military strategy . The Spanish troops were largely untrained conscripts, poorly equipped, and with low morale . The Spanish army also suffered from corruption and incompetence ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Causes and Contributing Factors"

                                ],
                                "text": "The disaster at Annual triggered a political crisis in Spain, leading to protests and the resignation of the government . The defeat led to 'humiliation du corps militaire' and 'frustration coloniale,' fueling a loss of confidence in parliamentary institutions . The defeat also contributed to a sentiment in Spain that Morocco was a burden . General Juan Picasso was ordered to prepare a report (Expediente Picasso) on the events at Annual, which highlighted multiple military errors and negligence . The Expediente Picasso stated that 13,363 men died (10,973 Spaniards and 2,390 indigenous) compared to 1,000 Riffians . The Picasso investigation revealed corruption and incompetence within the Spanish army ."

The Republic of the Rif was a direct consequence of the Spanish disaster, providing an opportunity for independence from European and Moroccan control ."

The dictatorship of Primo de Rivera, starting in 1923, saw a rise in Hispano-Americanism used as a political tool for nationalization and cultural diplomacy ."

                                "text": "Following the Disaster of Annual, Spain launched a forceful counterattack known as the 'campaña del desquite' that involved increased troop deployments, war materials, and medical supplies . The Spanish reoccupation of Monte Arruit on October 24th revealed the massacre of over 2,000 Spanish soldiers after their surrender . The Alhucemas landing in 1925, a joint Spanish-French military operation, marked a turning point, leading to the defeat of Abd el-Krim and the Rif rebellion . Abd el-Krim surrendered to French forces in May 1926 . The Rif War officially ended in 1927 ."

                        "subtitle": "Spanish Response and the End of the Rif War"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s5_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://shs.cairn.info/article/STRAT_093_0491"
                                ],
                                "text": "Following the defeat at Annual, the Spanish authorities decided to employ chemical weapons to end the Rifian insurrection . Général Dámaso Berenguer, the Spanish High Commissioner in Tetouan, expressed his intention to use asphyxiating gas with \"true delight\" . Spain produced and used chemical weapons (phosgene, chloropicrine, and yperite) against the Rif rebels between 1921 and 1927 . King Alphonse XIII of Spain stated in 1925 that \"with the help of the most harmful gas\" they would save many Spanish and French lives and that the Beni Ourriaguel and tribes closer to Abdelkrim should be exterminated like bad animals ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Use of Chemical Weapons"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s6_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://cvc.cervantes.es/literatura/aih/pdf/14/aih_14_3_071.pdf",
                                    "https://gredos.usal.es/handle/10366/148738",
                                    "https://www.sinpermiso.info/textos/el-lado-humano-de-la-derrota-el-desastre-de-annual-en-iman-de-ramon-j-sender"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Disaster of Annual had a profound impact on Spanish society and was reflected in Spanish literature and art . Ramón J. Sender's novel 'Iman' (1930) reconstructs the Disaster of Annual through the eyes of Viance, a common soldier, critiquing the colonial policies of the Spanish state . The novel was written to counter the 'official discourse' that hid the suffering of ordinary soldiers . The Poem of Dhar Oubarran, a 1921 Rif poetic epic, critiques the behaviors and actions of Spain during the Battle of Annual from the local Rif perspective ."
                            },
                            {

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/polit_0032-342x_1937_num_2_6_6327?h=pacification&h=maroc"
                                ],
                                "text": "In the early 20th century, Morocco was a land of diverse cultures and languages, including Arabic and Berber (also known as Amazigh) . The Alawite dynasty theoretically united the country, but in practice, Morocco consisted of numerous small, independent states . The Sultan's authority was largely confined to cities and major routes, with religious fiefdoms, temporal principalities, and Berber republics also existing . The French Protectorate was established in 1912 through the Treaty of Fez, placing Morocco under French control while ceding a coastal area along the Strait of Gibraltar to Spain . This treaty allowed France to occupy parts of Morocco under the guise of protecting the sovereign . The French Resident-General gained the sole right to represent Morocco in foreign countries ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s0_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-78664-3_3",

                                    "https://theses.cz/id/8jep7t/Les_relations_franco-marocaines_au_XXe_et_XXIe_sicle.pdf"
                                ],
                                "text": "Prior to the French Protectorate, Spain and France had been vying for influence in Morocco . The Act of Algeciras in 1906 granted France partial control of customs and the National Bank of Morocco . The French colonial administration, under Marshal Lyautey, aimed to modernize the country while preserving its traditions . However, this approach was not always consistent, and tensions arose between the French administration and Moroccan society ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Context"

                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://brill.com/downloadpdf/view/journals/afoc/18/1-2/article-p59_5.pdf",
                                    "https://ddd.uab.cat/pub/caplli/2018/294337/sigmovsocmar_a2018p163.pdf",

                                    "https://minpaku.repo.nii.ac.jp/record/8694/files/SER152_06.pdf",
                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1984_num_38_1_2047"
                                ],
                                "text": "On May 16, 1930, the French Protectorate authorities promulgated the Berber Dahir (also referred to as the Berber Decree), a decree that formalized the tribal law system (droit coutumier) in Berber-dominant rural areas of Morocco . The Dahir divided the French Protectorate into zones governed by Sharia law and Berber customary law . It aimed to adapt Berber justice to modern conditions, following the spirit of the Dahir of September 11, 1914, signed by Lyautey . The policy sought to preserve Berber autonomy, especially in legal matters, by keeping them outside Islamic law (Chrâa) and maintaining their customary law (Orf or Izref) . The administration was tasked with defining Berber laws and designating Berber tribes, primarily based on submission to military authorities ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://ddd.uab.cat/pub/caplli/2018/294337/sigmovsocmar_a2018p163.pdf",
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/2361"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Dahir also imposed the supremacy of French law in Berber regions . Article 6 of the Dahir Berbère stated that French courts were competent to repress crimes committed in Berber regions regardless of the status of the perpetrator ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Berber Dahir of 1930"

                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1984_num_38_1_2047"
                                ],
                                "text": "The Berber Dahir was met with widespread opposition from Moroccan nationalists, who viewed it as an attempt to divide the country and Christianize the Berbers . Nationalists framed the Dahir as an attempt to abolish Islamic law . The decree was seen as an assault on Muslim identity . The protests against the Berber Dahir began in Salé a few weeks after its promulgation, centered around the recitation of the latif, a collective prayer invoking God in situations of disaster . The protests spread from Salé to other cities like Rabat, Fez, and Casablanca ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p1",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://ddd.uab.cat/pub/caplli/2018/294337/sigmovsocmar_a2018p163.pdf",
                                    "https://www.persee.fr/doc/camed_0395-9317_1979_num_19_1_1462"
                                ],
                                "text": "The protests helped to unify an emerging Moroccan nationalist movement . The national movement was founded on the sentiment of belonging to the Islamic community and the Arab nation . The feeling of belonging to the Muslim community (al-ummat al-islamîya) was a dominant factor in this nationalism . The protests took place during a period of economic uncertainty, including the global crisis of 1929 and local issues like droughts and locust plagues ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s2_p2",

Abdelatif Subihi, an employee of the colonial administration and graduate of the School of Oriental Languages in Paris, played a key role in initiating the protests in Salé . The anniversary of the Berber Dahir on May 16th was commemorated annually with gatherings in mosques to recite the latif ."
                            }

In January 1931, 12 Islamic associations in Java created a Muslim Committee for the defense of the Berbers . The Islamic Congress of Jerusalem in December 1931 approved a declaration calling on France to withdraw the Dahir . Letters of protest were sent from the Pan-Islamic Congress and the Associations of Young Muslims from other regions of the Arab world ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The French Protectorate in Morocco, established by the Treaty of Fez in 1912, significantly curtailed the power of the Sultan and the Makhzen . While the Sultan remained, the French Résident Général acted as the sole intermediary between the monarch and foreign representatives . This system, along with the Spanish Protectorate in the northern Rif region and parts of the south, sparked growing nationalist sentiment among Moroccans . Sidi Mohammed, later known as Mohammed V, became Sultan in 1927 and emerged as a symbol of this nationalist movement ."
                            },
                            {

The \"Berber Dahir\" of 1930, which aimed to implement customary law in Berber-speaking regions, triggered widespread protests . The nationalist party Istiqlal (Independence) was founded in 1944 and played a central role in the fight for independence . During World War II, Mohammed V sided with the Allies and implicitly supported the Istiqlal party . His speech in Tangier on April 10, 1947, deviated from the approved text, further straining relations with the French . General Alphonse Juin aimed to force the sultan \"to submit or resign\" . Thami El Glaoui, Pacha of Marrakech, was used to oppose Mohammed V ."

                                ],
                                "text": "On August 20, 1953, France deposed Sultan Mohammed V of Morocco . This action was a violation of the Treaty of Protectorate and considered sacrilegious by Muslims . The French authorities removed him from his religious authority and exiled him, first to Corsica and then, in January 1954, to Antsirabe, Madagascar . Mohammed Ben Arafa was installed as the new 'imam' . The leaders of the Moroccan national movement conditioned independence on the return of Mohammed V from exile ."
                            },
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p1",

                                ],
                                "text": "The exile triggered a wave of nationalist violence in Morocco . A popular uprising against foreign domination occurred in the Maghreb region . The Moroccan people engaged in a popular rebellion and resistance against foreign domination during the colonial period . The exile caused an explosion of popular anger, increased insecurity, and terrorism . Nationalist violence led to 839 deaths between 1953 and 1955 . The Moroccan resistance movement involved people from all levels of society who risked their lives for their country's liberation . Resistance fighters were driven by patriotism and a willingness to make sacrifices ."

The \"yaouleds\" (street children) of Casablanca participated in the riots of December 1952, protesting the inequalities of the protectorate system ."

                                ],
                                "text": "The Byzantine reconquest of North Africa, a significant military campaign in the 6th century, was undertaken by Emperor Justinian I . This event occurred within a broader historical context of shifting power dynamics in the Mediterranean, following the decline of the Western Roman Empire and the rise of new powers, including the Vandal kingdom in North Africa . The Vandals, after crossing the Gibraltar Strait in 429 CE and capturing Carthage in 439 CE, controlled the region for approximately a century . The Byzantine Empire, seeking to restore Roman imperial authority, viewed the Vandal kingdom as an illegitimate power and a threat to its interests ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Background and Context"
                    },
                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s1_p0",

                                ],
                                "text": "Several factors motivated Justinian's decision to launch the reconquest. One of the main reasons was religious, aiming to liberate the African Catholic population from Arian Vandal persecution . The African Catholic clergy enthusiastically welcomed the Byzantine conquest, as evidenced in a letter to Pope John II in May 535 . Justinian also sought to re-establish Roman control over vital economic resources in North Africa, including its agricultural lands and trade networks . The reconquest was seen as a political liberation of Roman people from barbarian oppressors ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Motivations for the Reconquest"

                                ],
                                "text": "The Byzantine military campaign was initiated in 533 CE under the leadership of General Belisarius . The expeditionary force, though including Arian soldiers, mainly barbarians, was largely composed of Byzantine troops . Belisarius's amphibious assault proved successful, leading to decisive victories against the Vandals at Ad Decimum on September 13, 533, and Tricamarum in 534 CE . King Gelimer, who reigned from June 15, 530, to September 15, 533, was captured and sent to Byzantium . The Vandal kingdom was dismantled, and North Africa was brought back under Byzantine control . The celebration of St. Cyprian's Day in Carthage on September 14, 533, occurred after the Arian priests fled following Gelimer's defeat at Ad Decimum ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "The Military Campaign (533-534 CE)"

                    {
                        "paragraphs": [
                            {
                                "paragraph_id": "s3_p0",
                                "source_URLs": [
                                    "https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/224048137.pdf",
                                    "https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/pdf/83#page=9",
                                    "https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/traditio/article/arianism-and-the-byzantine-army-in-africa-533546/A6A4A7B40AF1A26A321E616A177E93D1"
                                ],
                                "text": "Despite the initial success, the Byzantine reconquest faced numerous challenges. Belisarius's initial distrust of the African population was evident in security measures following the landing in 533 . A major revolt of Arian troops occurred in the spring of 536, taking the authorities by surprise . This revolt was partly caused by Justinian's anti-Arian policies and the actions of Vandal Arian clergymen who incited the soldiers . Vandal women also played a significant role in the 536 revolt, urging their husbands to reclaim land and opposing the suppression of Arianism . Subsequent rebellions, led by Stotzas (536-546) and Guntharic (546), continued to involve Arian soldiers and Vandals . The Laguatan, a Berber tribal confederation, also posed a significant challenge to Byzantine authority . In 523 AD, a Vandal army was defeated in Tripolitania by the Laguatan under Cabaon . In 543 AD, 79 Laguatan chiefs were killed at a meeting with Dux Sergius at Lepcis, leading to a major revolt lasting until 548 AD ."
                            }
                        ],
                        "subtitle": "Challenges and Rebellions (534-548 CE)"

                                "text": "Following the reconquest, the Byzantine Empire implemented administrative and societal changes in North Africa. The administration primarily consisted of individuals from the Eastern Roman Empire, leading to the \"Byzantinization of African society\" . The Codex Justinianus mentions the Tripolitanian province's military commander temporarily residing at Lepcis Magna . The African Catholic clergy played a significant role in resisting Byzantine imperial attempts to subvert Chalcedonian orthodoxy . The African Church resisted imperial interference during the \"three chapters\" controversy under Emperor Justinian . The Byzantine presence also led to a revival of trans-Saharan trade, which had ended with the fall of Roman rule . Christianity spread to the Fezzan following the Byzantine reconquest ."

                                "text": "Despite Justinian's efforts, the Byzantine presence in North Africa was ultimately unsustainable. The lands gained in North Africa by Belisarius were lost a few years after Justinian's death in 565 CE . Between 632 and 670 CE, Muslim Arabs conquered Near Eastern and North African lands previously under Byzantine control . The armies of Mohammad conquered Byzantine provinces in Asia and Africa during the early 7th century . Antioch was lost to the Arabs in 637 CE . The Arab invasion of Egypt began in 639 CE . The fall of Alexandria in 642 CE ended Byzantine rule in Egypt . Constans II's attempts to secure Italy and North Africa were part of a strategy to regain the initiative from the Arabs . The Arab conquest marks the end of the period covered in the excerpt ."

It marked a period of renewed Roman influence, religious revival, and economic activity . The Byzantine presence also contributed to the cultural and artistic landscape of North Africa, as evidenced by the blend of Roman, Constantinopolitan, and Syrian influences in Byzantine religious art . The reconquest also set the stage for the subsequent Arab conquest, which would fundamentally reshape the region's history and culture ."

                                "text": "The region of North Africa known as Mauretania, inhabited by the Mauri people , had a complex relationship with Rome long before its formal annexation. By the mid-2nd century BC, most Mediterranean states were politically tied to Rome, with Mauretania being a notable exception . Initially, Rome's approach to Mauretania mirrored Carthage's, focusing on trade rather than territorial acquisition . The Phoenicians had established trading colonies in North Africa , and Carthage had commercial relations with Numidia and Mauretania . The Mauri lived between the Atlantic coast and the Moulouya River, while the Numidians resided between the Mauri and western Carthaginian territory ."

The Vandals underwent a transformation from primarily farmers to a society centered on horse breeding and mounted warfare, heavily influenced by Sarmatians and Alans .                     }
                ]
            }
        ]
    }
]
